24 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"c87f23d79266fbdf7d58032e096e9810","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn27@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109662669_868ae319e34b4d11.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn27@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109662669_868ae319e34b4d11.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn2@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109673281_74d7fa1de10ff3a9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn46@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109672142_16fba4c1eea00483.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-04.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-04.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn1@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109677357_47e9e7130117c894.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-05.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-05.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn41@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109674982_24a01cb5e08f15cd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/59/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn69@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676947_d47347ecf7f0e8e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn93@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675633_102c6afc9d7a4ff9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-08.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-08.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn41@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674458_1b3a16b3763e1502.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/63/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-09.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-09.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn65@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109670882_6a4c6d26accbb865.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn45@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109671264_ea9a923eb643b7e7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn86@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672374_6dc0d37dcb1bacc2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg/aid11554424-v4-728px-Try-CBD-Oil-for-the-First-Time-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn5@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109673909_9b3d6063a1f4c977.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Crochet a Celtic Square","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Celtic squares are great crochet projects that use only a small amount of yarn. While they look complex at first glance, they are actually fairly easy to make and don't take up a lot of time. This wikiHow will teach you how to make this fun crochet project.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Crochet-a-Celtic-Square&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Crochet-a-Celtic-Square&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making the Center Square\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-the-Center-Square\">Making the Center Square</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Grab the yarn of your choice. Now do a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Slip-Knot\" title=\"Make a Slip Knot\">slip knot</a>. One way to do this is to fold the yarn and hold it between your thumb and index finger. Twist the string to form a loop, and pull the rest of the yarn through the loop. Then insert your crochet hook into the loop left.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Chain 28. To do a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Crochet-a-Chain\" title=\"Crochet a Chain\">chain stitch</a>, yarn over once to get two loops on your hook. Pull the first loop through the second loop to finish the chain stitch. Repeat this 27 more times before moving on to the next step.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Slip stitch into the first chain. To do this, insert your hook into the first chain. Yarn over while your hook is still in the chain.&#160; Pull the loop you thread over through the first chain and the other loop. You should see a circle/square like shape forming now.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Chain 3. After the slip stitch, chain 3. This is to prepare for the double crochet that you will be doing afterwards.<br /><br /></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Do-Double-Crochet\" title=\"Do Double Crochet\">Double crochet</a> into the next stitch. Start the double crochet by yarning over once. Insert your hook into the next stitch, and yarn over again with your hook in the stitch this time. Pull all the loops through the stitch. You should now have 3 loops on your hook. Yarn over again and pull through two loops. Yarn over one last time and pull through the remaining loops.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>This stitch can also be called treble crochet in UK.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Do 4 double crochets in the next stitch. This reason to do four is because this is a corner, and you need four to help you turn and change direction.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Double crochet in each of the next six chain stitches. There should be only one in each stitch now, as this is not at a corner.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Do 4 double crochets in the next stitch, again. This is a corner once more, which is why there are four double crochets crowded in one stitch.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Repeat. Double crochet in each of the next six chain stitches, do a corner; repeat this until you get to the first double crochet made.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Slip stitch into the 3rd chain of the first double crochet. This 3rd chain was formed when you chained 3; so slip stitch into it. Now, you should be able to see the square shape clearly.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Finish off the square. Do a chain stitch, and pull tightly to form it into a knot. Cut the thread, and weave in the ends.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-11.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Crochet-a-Celtic-Square&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making the Ovals\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-the-Ovals\">Making the Ovals</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Get another yarn that is a different color from the center square. Do a slip knot, and chain 36.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-12.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Double crochet in the fourth chain from the hook. Then do another double crochet in the stitch after.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Do a corner. This is the same as for the center square: four double crochets.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Double crochet in each of the next 16 chains.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>Be sure to count the exact number. If you are having trouble keeping track, try counting out loud.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Do a corner again.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-16.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Double crochet in each of the next 14 chains. You can now finish it off. This time, however, do <i>not</i> weave in the ends. You will need them for closing the oval later.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-17.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Repeat the steps to make a second unclosed-oval. This one, however, should be made of yarn that is a different color from both the center square's <i>and</i> the other oval.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Crochet a Celtic Square Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-18.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Crochet-a-Celtic-Square&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Assembling the Pieces\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Assembling-the-Pieces\">Assembling the Pieces</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Grab the center square and one of the unclosed-ovals. Take one end of the unclosed-oval. Weave the end over one side of the square and under the opposite side. Now take the other end and do the same, except opposite: weave the end under the first side and over the opposite side.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Take the loose string. Weave it back and forth between the two ends. This will close the previously unclosed-oval. Then weave the remaining part of the string in.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Grab the other oval (that is still separate from the center square). Like before, take one end of it. This time, though, weave the end over one of the two sides of the square that has not been woven by yet, under one side of the other oval, over the other side of the other oval, and under the opposite side of the square. Then take the other end and reverse the process: under, over, under, over.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Close the unclosed-oval as you did for the other oval. Your Celtic square is now finished!<br /><br /></li></ol>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Crochet-a-Celtic-Square&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"7be0fee6027b664e91d7eed3e607b9dc","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn47@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662855_1409d76d1709092a.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn47@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662855_1409d76d1709092a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-11.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn74@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109672175_f425935581e37b86.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-12.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn70@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109672232_1905c1f58608ea48.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-16.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn58@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672133_cda72970916d3782.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-17.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn22@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673511_e4d7b910a7966d5c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-18.jpg/aid11210329-v4-728px-Crochet-a-Celtic-Square-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn89@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673322_195d0f1fa45ca19a.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Make Emoji Cookies","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Emoji-Cookies","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Emojis have taken over the language of texting. Instead of sending LOL, you can use a smiley face or a laughing Emoji. Instead of sending your love, you can just send a heart. You can turn these funny faces into cookies to dazzle your friends and family by making sugar cookies as a base and using royal icing to decorate them.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Sugar Cookies\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sugar-Cookies\">Sugar Cookies</span></h3>\n<ul><li>1 cup (227 g) of softened butter</li>\n<li>1.5 cups (300 g) of granulated sugar</li>\n<li>1 large egg</li>\n<li>of vanilla extract</li>\n<li>2.75 cups (398 g) of flour</li>\n<li>1 tsp (13 g) of baking soda</li>\n<li>1/2 tsp (6.5 g) of baking powder</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Frosting Base\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Frosting-Base\">Frosting Base</span></h3>\n<ul><li>4 cups (500 g) of confectioners' sugar</li>\n<li>3 tablespoons (30 g) of meringue powder</li>\n<li>1/2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of extract (vanilla, lemon, almond)</li>\n<li>1/2 to 3/4 cup (120 to 180 mL) of warm water</li>\n<li>Food coloring</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Baking Sugar Cookies\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Baking-Sugar-Cookies\">Baking Sugar Cookies</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Preheat your oven to . Turn your oven on before you start mixing your ingredients, so it will be ready for your cookies. Keep it at  so your cookies bake to the perfect consistency.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Combine butter and sugar in a large bowl. Mix together 1 cup (227 g) of softened butter and 1.5 cups (300 g) of granulated sugar with a baking spatula. Mix them together until they make a smooth mixture.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you have a store-bought sugar cookie mix, you can use that instead.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Beat in 1 egg and vanilla extract. Crack 1 large egg into the bowl and make sure there are no egg shells. Pour in  of vanilla extract and stir your mixture until it is smooth.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Use imitation vanilla extract for a cheaper option.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Blend in flour, baking soda, and baking powder. Add 2.75 cups (398 g) of flour, 1 tsp (13 g) of baking soda, and 1/2 tsp (6.5 g) of baking powder to your bowl. Stir them in gradually with a baking spatula until your mixture is combined and makes a soft dough.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Try not to overmix your dough, or you could cause your dough to become more dense.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Roll out your dough with a rolling pin. Pour a thin layer of flour out on a countertop or cutting board. Use a rolling pin to spread your dough out until it is about  thick.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Using flour helps the dough become less sticky and roll out smoother.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use cookie cutters to cut out circles, hearts, and other Emoji shapes. Place a few different cookie cutter shapes, like circles and hearts to make shapes for your Emojis. Cut out all of your shapes until you run out of dough.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Circles are great for Emoji faces, and you can even use the top of a Christmas tree cookie cutter to make the poo Emoji.</li>\n<li>Add small horns to the top of a circle cookie to make a devil Emoji shape.</li>\n<li>Use a unicorn outline cookie cutter for a cute unicorn Emoji.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Lay your cookies out on a cookie sheet. Gently pull your shapes up and out of the dough. Lay them out on a baking tray with about  in between each cookie.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Since sugar cookies have a lot of butter in them, you don’t need to grease your baking tray.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Bake your cookies for 8 to 10 minutes. Set your cookies on the middle rack of your oven and take them out when they are hard around the edges. Make sure your cookies don’t get too brown, or they could burn.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Take your cookies out and let them cool. Set your baking tray on your stove top to let your cookies cool down. Wait for about 1 hour or until they get to room temperature.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you have a cooling rack, use a spatula to transfer them there to make them cool down faster.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Adding a Frosting Base\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adding-a-Frosting-Base\">Adding a Frosting Base</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Make a batch of <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Royal-Icing\" title=\"Make Royal Icing\">royal icing</a>. Combine 4 cups (500 g) of confectioners' sugar, 3 tablespoons (30 g) of meringue powder, 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 mL) of vanilla extract, and  of water in a mixing bowl. Mix them up until you have smooth and creamy frosting.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you have an electric mixer, you can use that to combine your ingredients quickly.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add 1 drop of food coloring to small portions of icing. Separate your icing batch into 5 to 6 small, equal portions. Add yellow, pink, red, brown, and black food coloring to 1 bowl of frosting at a time, and leave 1 pure white. Mix together your food coloring and frosting to create bright, vibrant colors.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you aren’t planning on making a poo Emoji, you don’t need any brown frosting.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Put your frosting into piping bags. Use a baking spatula to spoon different frosting colors into piping bags. Cut the tip off of each bag for a small hole that your frosting can come out of.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you don’t have a piping bag, you can <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Piping-Bag\" title=\"Make a Piping Bag\">make your own</a> by stapling together parchment paper in a triangle.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Make a yellow base on each circle cookie. Draw a yellow outline in frosting around the edge of each circle cookie. Use the frosting to fill in the circle and then let it sit for 10 minutes to harden.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Letting the frosting harden makes it a better base so it won’t blend with your other colors.</li>\n<li>You can also use a purple base for a devil Emoji cookie, or a white base for a unicorn cookie.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Decorate your heart cookies with pink or red frosting. Pipe an outline of frosting around the edges of each heart cookie. Use the same frosting to fill in the insides of the heart, and then let your cookies sit for at least 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Add brown frosting to your poo Emoji cookie. Use brown frosting in a piping bag to make a thin outline around your Christmas tree cookie. Then, fill in the middle with the brown frosting and let your cookie sit for 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><br /><br /></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Piping the Details of Your Cookies\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Piping-the-Details-of-Your-Cookies\">Piping the Details of Your Cookies</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Add a white mouth and closed eyes for the smiling emoji. Pipe a rectangular outline near the bottom of a yellow circle cookie and fill it in with white frosting. Use black frosting to create a grid of top and bottom teeth inside the mouth. Then, draw 2 closed eyes in a half moon shape up above for a cute, happy Emoji.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>This is one of the simplest face Emojis to decorate.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pipe black sunglasses and a smile for the sunglasses Emoji. Outline thin black sunglasses near the top of a circle cookie. Fill in each lens so they are completely black. Then, pipe a thin smiling mouth underneath the glasses. Let your cookie dry for 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Add white eyes and a smile to your poo Emoji. Pipe 2 small ovals near the top of your poo Emoji cookie. Use the same white frosting to make a smiling mouth underneath the eyes. Then, add 2 small black dots on the eyes to make pupils and let your cookie dry for about 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Draw a red heart onto a kissing face for the kissing Emoji. Pipe 1 full eye and 1 winking eye at the top of a yellow circle cookie. Use the same black frosting to make a mouth by drawing a 3 on your cookie. Then, pipe a small red heart near the mouth and fill it in completely. Let your cookie dry for 10 minutes before you serve it.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can also add eyebrows to this Emoji to make it more realistic.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add blue tears to the laughing Emoji. Pipe 2 eyes in half moon shapes to look like they are closed. Add some raised eyebrows in black above each eye. Use white and black frosting to pipe an open, smiling mouth with a line of white teeth. Then, use blue frosting to pipe 2 large blue tears coming out of the eyes of your Emoji.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>The laughing Emoji is one of the most easily recognizable Emojis.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use hearts for eyes for the heart-eyes Emoji. Pipe 2 small hearts in the place of eyes near the top of a yellow circle cookie. Add a simple black mouth that is smiling underneath the eyes for a cute, easily recognizable heart-eyes cookie.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can also use large heart sprinkles for the eyes if you have them.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Decorate a purple cookie with a mean face for the devil Emoji. Draw 2 circular black eyes in the middle of your cookie and put some thick black eyebrows that point downward on top. You can make your devil Emoji smile with a happy face or angry with a frowny face for an evil-looking cookie.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Since there are 2 devil Emojis, you can choose whichever one you want to make, or even do them both.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pipe a small rainbow onto a circle cookie for a rainbow Emoji. Take a blank cookie and use red, yellow, blue, and green to pipe the lines of a rainbow in the center. Use white frosting to make clouds on either side of the emoji, or leave it blank for a more realistic rainbow.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-23-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Emoji Cookies Step 23 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-23-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-23-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Add some edible glitter on top of your cookie for an added sparkle.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Mixing bowl</li>\n<li>Baking spatula</li>\n<li>Baking tray</li>\n<li>Piping bags</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Look at the Emojis on your phone for a guide as you decorate your cookies.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Emoji-Cookies&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-21\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://chocolatecoveredkatie.com/2016/09/29/how-to-make-emoji-cookies-recipe/\">https://chocolatecoveredkatie.com/2016/09/29/how-to-make-emoji-cookies-recipe/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-23\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://chocolatecoveredkatie.com/2016/09/29/how-to-make-emoji-cookies-recipe/\">https://chocolatecoveredkatie.com/2016/09/29/how-to-make-emoji-cookies-recipe/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"00456493ad8412d3873d1e2bc3b2d804","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn3@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662671_78d089356449c5c7.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn3@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662671_78d089356449c5c7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn69@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109675175_a444aaf844da0676.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn18@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672061_38b7714ffa62359e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn5@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675667_b112f7657e316e5e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn98@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673932_1cbf2dccd1461815.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-23-Version-2.jpg/aid11763829-v4-728px-Make-Emoji-Cookies-Step-23-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn45@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674973_d52b0a1e9f306683.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Identify a Pug","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-Pug","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Pugs are the largest of the toy dog breeds,<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> with a unique appearance and lovable personality. They can easily be confused with other dog breeds, however, such as a French bulldog or Pekingese. If you take a closer look at a dog's physical characteristics and temperament, you can more easily discover whether or not the dog is a pug.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Recognizing Body Structure\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Recognizing-Body-Structure\">Recognizing Body Structure</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Pay attention to the dog's size. Being a member of the toy group, the pug is a smaller dog breed. They tend to weigh around , standing  tall.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Look at the tail of the dog. A pug's tail is known for being curled. The tail of a pug should be curled (preferable double-curled) over the dog's hip tightly.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> The tail lays upward on the edge of the back in its curled position.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Identify-a-Pug-Step-2.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Notice the dog's head shape. The AKC standards state that a pug's head shape should be \"large, massive, [and] round\".<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup> Pugs also have <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Pug%27s-Facial-Wrinkles\" title=\"Clean a Pug&#39;s Facial Wrinkles\">deep wrinkles</a> on their short and flat muzzles, between their eyes, and around their faces.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Identify-a-Pug-Step-3.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>See if the dog has dark, prominent eyes. Pugs have round, bold eyes. Their eyes are usually a dark color, such as brown. They are large and noticeable in shape,<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> and sit across from the dark black nose.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Identify-a-Pug-Step-4.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Look for small ears that rest atop the dog's head. A pug's ears are either classified as \"rose\" or \"button\" type ears. \"Rose\" ears refer to small, folded ears with edges touching the side of the head. \"Button\" ears are not as short and are folded more forward rather than on the side of the head.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> The AKC standards describe a pug's ears as being similar to \"black velvet\".<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Identify-a-Pug-Step-5.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>See if the dog's build fits the motto <i>multum in parvo</i> (\"a lot in a little\"). A pug's build is small, square, and muscular.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> They have stubby and short legs. Their legs are also straight and sturdy, with shoulders that are slightly laid back and feet that are neither too round nor too long. The overall body shape of a pug is thick and stocky.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Identify-a-Pug-Step-6.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Identifying the Coat\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Identifying-the-Coat\">Identifying the Coat</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Look at the dog's fur color. A pug is usually an apricot/fawn color or has an entirely black coat. However, pugs can also be seen in silver, white, or a brindle pattern<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>, which are more rare fur colors. Keep in mind that the AKC only recognizes the fawn and black variations.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-7.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If a pug is of the fawn variety, it will have a black or brownish \"mask\" around its eyes and muzzle. Fawn pugs are also seen with black dots on their cheeks and may have a black outline across their back.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Notice silver or grey markings near the muzzle and face. As a pug ages, the area around its mouth and muzzle may become lighter and appear as a silvery color. This occurs not just in solid black pugs, but in pugs of all color varieties. The back, ears, or other black-colored areas on a pug's body may also lighten.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-8.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Assess how the fur of the dog appears and feels. Pugs have sleek fur that sheds consistently.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> Their coat is \"fine, smooth, soft, short, and glossy\", according to the AKC.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> Some dogs of this breed have double coats.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Identify-a-Pug-Step-9.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Paying Attention to Temperament\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Paying-Attention-to-Temperament\">Paying Attention to Temperament</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Look for playfulness and an overall attention-seeking, \"goofy\" personality, especially from younger dogs. Pugs love being the center of attention. However, as they age, their energy may slowly decrease. A pug puppy will be after your attention and may make some trouble. They are curious and love to express their energy, and they are very eager-to-please.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Identify-a-Pug-Step-10.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Notice if the dog is stubborn. Pugs don't always have the easiest time listening to what they're told. If the dog likes to do what they want rather than obeying, understand that this breed of dog is naturally stubborn. Giving a pug proper training can help it to learn how to obey commands with more ease.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Identify-a-Pug-Step-11.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Watch for a guarding ability. Pugs make great watchdogs. They are attentive and will do what they can, despite their small size, to remain loyal and protecting of their owners. This is a desirable trait found in a dog.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Identify-a-Pug-Step-12.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Pay attention to the dog's intelligence. Along with being protective, pugs are smart dogs. They are fairly intelligent, which helps them with their guarding abilities. See how clever the canine is to help determine if they may be a pug.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Identify-a-Pug-Step-13.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>See if an older dog appears more docile. If the dog is older, rather than being energetic, it may be more willing to follow your directions. As they age, a pug may become more accepting of human control.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Identify-a-Pug-Step-14.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Being Aware of Similar Breeds\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Being-Aware-of-Similar-Breeds\">Being Aware of Similar Breeds</span></h3>\n<p>There are several other dog breeds that have similarities in appearance to a pug. However, if you are aware of the differences between the breeds, you can obtain a better understanding of whether or not a dog is a pug.\n</p>\n<ol><li>Know the differences between a pug and a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-Pekingese\" title=\"Identify a Pekingese\">Pekingese</a>. A Pekingese can seem exactly like a pug, especially if it has a short coat. Most Pekingese, however, have quite long fur. Both breeds have wrinkles and flat muzzles, but a Pekingese's tail won't be curled like a pug's - instead, it hangs over the dog's back. Pekingese can also come in different coat colors than pugs, though both can be seen in fawn and black. Despite having longer fur, Pekingese don't shed as much as pugs, but still a moderate amount.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Identify-a-Pug-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>See how <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-French-Bulldog\" title=\"Identify a French Bulldog\">French bulldogs</a> and pugs differ. French bulldogs are another popular breed with wrinkles and a flat muzzle. They are slightly bigger than pugs (and therefore not a member of the toy group), and have short, stubby tails. Their ears are perked, rather than the pug's folded ears. A solid black or tan and black Frenchie may have white markings on the chest or stomach, differentiating it from a pug.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Identify-a-Pug-Step-16.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Understand the differences between pugs and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-an-English-Bulldog\" title=\"Identify an English Bulldog\">bulldogs</a>. Two stubborn, flat-faced breeds, pugs and English bulldogs have a lot in common. For example, both have faces coated with wrinkles. However, bulldogs have short, stumpy tails, while pugs have longer, curled tails. Bulldogs can come in many more color varieties, such as brown or brown with white markings. Pugs are smaller than bulldogs, as bulldogs are members of the non-sporting group. Bulldogs also have different ears than pugs.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Identify-a-Pug-Step-17.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Spot differences between <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-Boston-Terrier\" title=\"Identify a Boston Terrier\">Boston terriers</a> and pugs. These two breeds are roughly equal in size and body structure. However, Boston terriers usually have perked up ears and stubby tails, and tend to be black and white, while black pugs aren't seen with white markings. They also have completely different origins - Boston terriers originate in the United States, while pugs date back to Ancient China.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Identify-a-Pug-Step-19.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Notice how pugs and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-Boxer-Dog\" title=\"Identify a Boxer Dog\">boxers</a> differ. Boxers are medium-sized dogs and larger than pugs, but the two both tend to have flat, black muzzles. A boxer can have either cropped or uncropped ears, along with a natural or docked tail. A boxer's natural tail is longer than a pug's and isn't curled, while the docked tail is very short. Boxers are usually brown or black in color, but also are seen in white, brindle, and more color variants. Pugs aren't typically seen in a brown coat.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-20.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 20.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Identify-a-Pug-Step-20.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-20.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Be aware of how pugs and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Identify-a-Mastiff\" title=\"Identify a Mastiff\">mastiffs</a> differ. Pugs and mastiffs may look a little similar in appearance, but mastiffs are much larger dogs. Pugs are small dogs (generally lap dogs) while mastiffs are large dogs. Mastiffs have long tails that don't curl over their backs. Both dogs have wrinkles, but mastiffs have usually larger muzzles.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Identify-a-Pug-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Identify a Pug Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Identify-a-Pug-Step-18.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you want to verify that the dog you own is a pug, consider using a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Test-Dog-DNA-and-Analyze-Parentage\" title=\"Test Dog DNA and Analyze Parentage\">DNA test</a>. This will confirm your dog's breed.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Identify-a-Pug&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span
