22 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"66d75bb469f62f762201353f9ecbd7a3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662600_6ab911555d2fbc98.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662600_6ab911555d2fbc98.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Identify-a-Pug-Step-2.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn6@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673276_7fee6e2c8e1ac9ad.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Identify-a-Pug-Step-3.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn57@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674497_9048de2a2db51170.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Identify-a-Pug-Step-4.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn94@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673846_621f2a1953c13608.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Identify-a-Pug-Step-5.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn21@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109672459_868de59ddc724478.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Identify-a-Pug-Step-6.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn97@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676178_a4332a2d0c209206.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-7.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn65@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674638_daf87b9a4cf8772f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Identify-a-Pug-Step-8.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn53@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672879_785a861fcaf5f35f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Identify-a-Pug-Step-9.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn61@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109674466_9ac6910fa5983d6e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Identify-a-Pug-Step-10.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674663_afca8459b9f91675.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Identify-a-Pug-Step-11.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn62@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673682_648b0527c3cd4364.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Identify-a-Pug-Step-12.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn25@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109671047_3cc05b6a7cd5a64f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Identify-a-Pug-Step-13.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676930_af716ee00085b9db.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Identify-a-Pug-Step-14.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn5@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109671565_bcad081fda75a385.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Identify-a-Pug-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn9@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674747_1e67605eec66652d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Identify-a-Pug-Step-16.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676961_be306fa059d9f18d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Identify-a-Pug-Step-17.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673237_ebac7e7602ce579d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Identify-a-Pug-Step-19.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn13@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109673875_6a2482da1ecab339.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Identify-a-Pug-Step-20.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-20.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn73@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674601_2a3b5252e2718c8e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7a/Identify-a-Pug-Step-18.jpg/aid11105717-v4-728px-Identify-a-Pug-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn6@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672014_3b6b2edc0ff6063a.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Dry Makeup Brushes","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Makeup-Brushes","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>It is important to properly dry your makeup brushes after you wash them. Otherwise, you could damage the bristles or allow bacteria to grow, negating the cleaning you just completed. With proper care, you can extend the life of your brushes so you can get the most use out of them.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Drying with a Towel\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Drying-with-a-Towel\">Drying with a Towel</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Set your brushes on a towel after you've washed them. You can use either a clean, dry bath towel, or a dry paper towel to start the drying process. A larger bath towel may work best, because it will absorb a lot of water and will be big enough to hold all of your brushes.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Set the towel on a flat surface, with the brushes an inch or two apart on top of it. Lay the brushes flat, because if you place them upright, the water won't be able to evaporate completely, which could lead to bacteria growth.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Leave about half of the towel empty.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Fold half of the towel over the brushes. You'll want to get some of the water out of your brushes before you set them up to dry. You can do this by folding the empty half of the towel over the brushes so they are completely surrounded by it.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-2.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Press gently on the towel. Using your hand, press gently on top of the towel. Do this for five or six seconds with each brush, so that the towel absorbs some of the water from the bristles.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-3.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Place the brushes on the counter edge. You want to make sure that the bristles of the brushes stick over the edge of the counter or shelf. That way, air circulates around the bristles and they do not rest on a damp surface. It will help the bristles to dry faster and keep them from acquiring bacteria.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-4.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Leave the brush handles on top of the towel, with just the bristles sticking out over the edge of the counter.</li>\n<li>While they dry, it's a good idea to turn on a fan, especially if they're in the bathroom. The fan will circulate the air, dispersing the moisture.</li>\n<li>It will usually take 3-4 hours for the brushes to dry completely.</li>\n<li>You'll want to check the bristles by touching them with you hand before you use them, to make sure they are dry.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Hanging Brushes to Dry\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hanging-Brushes-to-Dry\">Hanging Brushes to Dry</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Attach brushes to a clothes hanger. Using either rubber bands or hair ties, attach the handles of your brushes to the bottom of a clothes hanger. Make sure the bristles are facing down when you attach them. This will allow the bristles to maintain their shape, and allow air to circulate around the bristles.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-5.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can place the hanger anywhere, but make sure the bristles are free and not resting against anything.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Your brushes will dry fastest if you hang them over a fan in a well-ventilated room.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Buy a holder for your brushes. There are holders available for purchase that allow you to hang your brushes to dry. These holders allow you to insert each brush into its own hole upside down. Air can then circulate around the bristles. Because they're upside down, water won't seep down into them.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-6.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>These holders may be sold in different sizes for different sized brushes.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Place a towel under your brushes. With the brushes hanging from the clothes hanger, or the holder, water may drip from the bristles. Place a clean, dry bath towel or paper towel under the brushes to absorb any water.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Makeup Brushes Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-7.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Leave the brushes hanging with the bristles facing down for four or five hours.</li>\n<li>Thicker brushes may need a bit more time.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Use a cream cleanser to clean brushes with nylon bristles, or use water and brush cleaner for natural bristles.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n<li>If you wash your brushes before bed, you can let them dry overnight while you sleep. That way they are ready for you to use in the morning.</li>\n<li>You can place a fan near the brushes to help them dry a bit faster.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Do not dry your brushes with the bristles facing up. If you do this, the water will run down onto the handle and could damage the glue that holds the bristles to the handle. You can avoid this by drying brushes with the bristles facing down, or by drying the brushes on their side with the bristles protruding over a counter edge.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Makeup-Brushes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161362_b01]. April 14, 2020.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/\">https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.allure.com/story/how-clean-are-your-makeup-brus\">https://www.allure.com/story/how-clean-are-your-makeup-brus</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.makeup.com/right-way-to-dry-makeup-brushes\">https://www.makeup.com/right-way-to-dry-makeup-brushes</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/\">https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.glamour.com/story/found-the-very-best-way-to-dry\">https://www.glamour.com/story/found-the-very-best-way-to-dry</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161362_b01]. April 14, 2020.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/\">https://www.cosmopolitan.com/style-beauty/beauty/a9602752/drying-makeup-brushes-hack/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"b6f54b9f28c4ba22661c11fbb29cbd8f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn7@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662610_ac9e36cb528df937.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn7@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662610_ac9e36cb528df937.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/06/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-2.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn14@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109671948_5d3ba7183ceecf1a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-3.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn85@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109670909_9e9dd8512eb2f78d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-4.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn29@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109670889_5481164f9bb4fb66.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-5.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn61@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673088_50cc4467d966076e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/23/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-6.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn21@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676554_03766dcfc894bcfb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-7.jpg/aid10244930-v4-728px-Dry-Makeup-Brushes-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn26@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673446_0698e738891f29ac.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Finish Cutting Boards","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Finish-Cutting-Boards","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>If you’ve purchased a wooden cutting board, you’ll need to apply a finish to prevent the board from becoming damaged with use. The first step is to choose your preferred finish. Cutting-board finishes come in 2 categories: drying and non-drying. Drying oils require only a single application and soak deep into the wood fibers. Non-drying finishes do not dry or harden in the wood, and so will need frequent reapplication.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Cutting boards made from plastic do not need to be finished.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Selecting a Non-Drying Finish\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Selecting-a-Non-Drying-Finish\">Selecting a Non-Drying Finish</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Use mineral oil for an affordable, popular finish. Mineral oil applies easily onto the surface of a wooden cutting board. This option is water resistant, meaning that juicy foods like tomatoes or raw meat won’t leak fluids into your cutting boards. Mineral oil is actually derived from petroleum, but is completely food safe. Since it’s a non-drying oil, it won’t leave an aroma behind.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can purchase mineral oil at any kitchen store or woodworking store. Many large grocery stores also sell mineral oil.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Apply a mixture of beeswax and non-drying oil for an attractive finish. Beeswax and oil form a liquid mixture which soaks deep into the woodgrain. This is beneficial to your cutting board, since it makes the wood look attractive and repels water. But, like other non-drying oils, it will require frequent reapplication.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-2.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You don’t need to mix beeswax and oil yourself. Mixtures of beeswax and oil (most often at about a 1:5 ratio) are sold in woodworking stores and catalogs.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Opt for carnauba wax for a stiff, water-repelling finish. The texture of carnauba wax is similar to beeswax, but the wax itself dries harder than beeswax and is excellent at repelling liquids. Like beeswax, carnauba wax is typically blended with non-drying oil. If you’re planning to cut lots of water-retaining foods on the cutting board, carnauba wax may be your best choice.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-3.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Carnauba wax may be a little tricky to find. Check woodworking stores. If they don’t stock the wax, find an online woodworking catalog and order the wax from the website.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Choosing a Drying Finish\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Choosing-a-Drying-Finish\">Choosing a Drying Finish</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Finish your cutting board with pure tung oil for a durable finish. Tung oil is a thick substance that will dry and harden in the fiber of the wood. This gives strength to the cutting board and will make it highly water-resistant. Unlike non-drying finish options, tung oil does not need to be frequently re-applied.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-4.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can purchase tung oil at most woodworking stores and through online woodworking catalogs.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Select raw linseed oil for a cheap and easily attainable finish. Linseed oil is an FDA-approved food additive, meaning that it’s among the safest finishes you can put on a cutting board. You can purchase linseed oil at any kitchen-supply store or woodworking store. Many large supermarkets or home-supply stores will also sell it. Linseed is a drying oil, so you’ll need to let it sit out for 5–7 days before using the cutting board.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-5.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>However, linseed oil also has a few disadvantages. It takes a long time to set, meaning that the cutting board will need to sit out for a few hours after you’ve applied the oil. Linseed oil also isn’t very water resistant.</li>\n<li>Never apply boiled linseed to a cutting board. This processed oil contains metallic drivers and isn’t safe for consumption.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Opt for walnut oil for a dark, protective finish. Walnut oil is a durable, long-lasting finish that will provide a water-resistant coating to your cutting board. The curing time, though, is quite long. You’ll need to wait at least 4–5 days for the oil to dry.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> You can purchase walnut oil at any woodworking store or online catalog. Keep in mind, though, that walnut oil is very dark and will darken the color of the wood you apply it to.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Finish Cutting Boards Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-6.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Depending on how light or dark you’d like your cutting board to be, this could be a positive or negative aspect of using walnut oil.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Applying and Maintaining the Finish\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Applying-and-Maintaining-the-Finish\">Applying and Maintaining the Finish</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Wash the cutting board before finishing it. You don’t want to apply finish over bits of food or dirt on the cutting board. So, rinse the board off under running tap water. You can also rub it down with a small dollop of dish soap and a clean sponge.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>After you rinse it clean, let the board dry for about 30 minutes before applying finish.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Rub a  dollop of finish on each side of the cutting board. Pour out a small dollop of finish onto a clean cotton rag. Using the rag, rub the finish onto the cutting board in long horizontal strokes. Make sure to cover the entire surface of the cutting board so there are no gaps in the finish.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>Once the first side is finished, turn the cutting board over and rub another  dollop onto the second side.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Let the finish dry for several hours or days. Different types of oil will take different amounts of time to dry. Non-drying oils will dry in 3–4 hours, while drying oils may take up to 7 days to dry completely. You can tell when the finish is dry by running your fingertips over the wood. If the finish is dry, your fingers will come away clean. If it’s still wet, you’ll have an oily residue on your fingertips.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>While the cutting board is drying, leave it in on your countertop or another safe place where it won’t be disturbed by kids or pets.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Reapply non-drying oils when the wood begins to look dry. The frequency with which you’ll need to reapply non-drying oils will vary based on how often you use the cutting board. Most users will need to reapply the finish about once a month. This includes all non-drying oils like mineral oil and wax mixed with oils.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you neglect to reapply non-drying finish, your cutting board will dry out and fluids from the foods you cut will penetrate the wood.</li>\n<li>If you finished the cutting board with a drying oil, you won’t need to reapply the finish.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Finish</li>\n<li>Clean cotton cloth</li>\n<li>Dish soap</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Never apply a lacquer or a varnish to a cutting board. These finishes form a thin film over wood, which will flake off and get in your food when you’re using the cutting board.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Film-forming finishes will also quickly break down and allow liquids from the food you’re cutting to penetrate the cutting board.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Do not apply food-based cooking oils, like olive, vegetable, or canola oil, to your cutting board. As time passes, these oils will turn rancid in the wood.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Finish-Cutting-Boards&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol
