29 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"d384ba45f8682c2c9c5896034a427730","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn23@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662602_528d4b8ece5f1f5e.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn23@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662602_528d4b8ece5f1f5e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-2.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109671073_cc52be0c556f4bc3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-3.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn5@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109676261_b14f5f978435db30.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3f/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-4.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn42@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673477_b2dfc64c6b0f7683.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-5.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn17@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674311_b733c72b12122394.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-6.jpg/aid10350756-v4-728px-Finish-Cutting-Boards-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn69@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109674579_aa0494385aef6e90.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Make Chinese Pancakes (Bing)","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Bing, also known as a Chinese pancake, is a traditional Chinese recipe, similar to crepes or pancakes. It is commonly made of dough or 面 in Chinese and has a pancake-like consistency at the end. If this is already mouthwatering to you, be prepared to learn how to make this yummy recipe!\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cong You Bing\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cong-You-Bing\">Cong You Bing</span></h3>\n<ul><li>2 cups of flour</li>\n<li>1/4 teaspoon salt</li>\n<li>1 cup water</li>\n<li>Handful of spring onions</li>\n<li>1 teaspoon cooking oil</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Chunbing\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Chunbing\">Chunbing</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Flour</li>\n<li>Water</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Xianbing\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Xianbing\">Xianbing</span></h3>\n<ul><li>500g flour</li>\n<li>250g meat</li>\n<li>500g vegetable of your choice</li>\n<li>Water</li>\n<li>Oil</li>\n<li>1 teaspoon of salt</li>\n<li>Pepper</li>\n<li>Ginger powder</li>\n<li>Soybean sauce</li>\n<li>Minced green onion</li>\n<li>1 tablespoon Chinese black bean sauce</li>\n<li>1/2 teaspoon Asian pepper sauce</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Making Cong You Bing[1]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Making-Cong-You-Bing[1]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Cong-You-Bing.5B1.5D\">Making Cong You Bing<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup></span></h3>\n<ol><li>Combine the ingredients for the dough (flour, salt, and cooking oil). Knead the dough until it has a soft consistency that isn't too wet.<br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bing Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>During this time, you can adjust the consistency, for example, by adding more oil or flour.</li>\n<li>Make sure you have enough dough for your desired amount and size of the pancake.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Separate the dough into different pieces, the size that you want. If you want to make the pancake bigger, don't separate it too much, and vice versa.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can use a rolling pin to help with making a circle.</li>\n<li>Chinese Pancake is commonly made in a circle shape, but can be any shape you want!</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add spring onions to the dough. Cut the onions into tiny chunks and sprinkle it on the bing. This gives the flavour for the cong you bing.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>The name \"cong\" in cong you bing actually refers to the spring onions.</li>\n<li>These can also be called scallions, green onions, and onions.</li>\n<li>You can also knead the dough again to mix the onion in.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Fry both sides of the pancake on low-medium heat until the sides are golden brown. It typically takes 3-5 minutes per side.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>Remember to take it out before the sides get dark brown.</li>\n<li>Fry for a short time if you want soft pancake, and fry it for a longer time to make it crispeir.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Serve and enjoy! It can be eaten as a casual food, but can be incorporated into formal meals as well.<br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bing-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bing Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Make-Bing-Step-5.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Making Chunbing [2]\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Making-Chunbing-[2]\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Chunbing-.5B2.5D\">Making Chunbing <sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></span></h3>\n<p>This type of Bing, Chinese Pancake, is commonly eaten to celebrate the start of spring, as \"chun\" means \"spring\" in Chinese.\n</p>\n<ol><li>Make the dough. To do this, mix the flour and water until they form a nice consistency. It should be soft and not sticky. Make sure you have enough dough for your desired amount.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>Usually, the best flour to water ratio is 3:2.</li>\n<li>It's recommended to use hot water.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Cut the dough into pieces. Like the cong you bing, you can cut it into any shape you want, but a circle is usually preferred.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can also stack the pieces to form a thicker dough.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Cook the dough in a heated pan. While doing this, flip the dough over as needed. The sides usually will have brown spots around it.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Serve the chun bing with other savoury dishes. These can include tofu, eggs, meat, and vegetables. It's also possible to put some ingredients in on the pancake and roll it up.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can also spread a dip on it for extra flavour!</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Making Xianbing\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Xianbing\">Making Xianbing</span></h3>\n<p>This recipe makes ten xianbings.\n</p>\n<ol><li>Mix 250 grams of meat and 500 grams of vegetables separately and put them into separate bowls.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Mincing-Meat.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Mincing Meat.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Mincing-Meat.jpeg/728px-Mincing-Meat.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You may choose from cabbage, Chinese chives, and other vegetables.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Sprinkle the vegetables with one teaspoon salt and season the meat with one teaspoon salt, pepper, ginger powder, and one tablespoon minced green onion, vegetable oil, and soybean sauce. You may adjust the amount according to your preferences.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Seasoning-Meat.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Seasoning Meat.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Seasoning-Meat.jpeg/728px-Seasoning-Meat.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you chose a watery vegetable such as cabbage, you need to squeeze the water out after sprinkling it with salt. Let it sit for one to two hours and squeeze the water out with your hands.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Mix the vegetable and meat together after seasoning them and store in the refrigerator for an hour to let the seasonings flavor the mixture thoroughly.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Mixing-Vegetable-and-Meat.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Mixing Vegetable and Meat.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Mixing-Vegetable-and-Meat.jpeg/728px-Mixing-Vegetable-and-Meat.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Make the dough (the wrapper) in the meantime by combining 500 grams of flour with enough water to knead into a soft dough. Knead until smooth.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Xianbing-Wrapper-Dough.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Xianbing Wrapper Dough.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Xianbing-Wrapper-Dough.jpeg/728px-Xianbing-Wrapper-Dough.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Depending on where you are, you will need different amounts of water. You will need, for example, more water in arid regions than in humid regions. It is all a matter of personal preference. Some people like a softer dough, while others prefer a firmer texture.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Heat up the pan while still working on the dough. It will then be ready for you when you need to cook.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bing-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bing Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Make-Bing-Step-14.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Come back to the dough and divide it into ten equal pieces. Each dough will become a single wrapper for a single xianbing. Roll each one out into flat, round pieces, 10-centimeter in diameter.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Rolling-Dough-Out.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Rolling Dough Out.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Rolling-Dough-Out.jpeg/728px-Rolling-Dough-Out.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Scoop up some of the meat-vegetable mixture previously made onto a wrapper and close it up at the top by folding wrinkles on the top side. Flatten it lightly into a 1-centimeter thick round pad. Repeat with each wrapper.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Twisting-Wrapper-Into-Xianbing.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Twisting Wrapper Into Xianbing.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Twisting-Wrapper-Into-Xianbing.jpeg/728px-Twisting-Wrapper-Into-Xianbing.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Depending on your xianbing skills, you may add more or less filling. Try to add only enough filling that you know you can close up. Later on, when you become more and more skilled, experiment with more filling and thinner wrappers.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add enough oil to cover the bottom of the pan and place the uncooked xianbings in it. Place a lid on the pan and wait for two minutes, after which you will need to flip the xianbings. It will be done when both sides are cooked golden yellow.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Xianbing-Almost-Done.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Xianbing Almost Done.jpeg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Xianbing-Almost-Done.jpeg/728px-Xianbing-Almost-Done.jpeg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You probably cannot add all the xianbings into the pan at once unless you have an extremely large pan. Feel free to cook them in different batches.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Chinese-Pancakes-(Bing)&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/264199/cong-you-bing-chinese-scallion-pancakes/\">https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/264199/cong-you-bing-chinese-scallion-pancakes/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://redhousespice.com/easy-chinese-tortilla/\">https://redhousespice.com/easy-chinese-tortilla/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 26 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"f22d7225e7765a1f683dd383c21da779","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662465_3e13b1081b17a7e3.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662465_3e13b1081b17a7e3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/44/Make-Bing-Step-5.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn58@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109673576_c2c4ed3691e851e5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Mincing-Meat.jpeg/728px-Mincing-Meat.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn93@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109677262_c68245a0e39eee9b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Seasoning-Meat.jpeg/728px-Seasoning-Meat.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn69@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673189_0454154c92e87135.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Mixing-Vegetable-and-Meat.jpeg/728px-Mixing-Vegetable-and-Meat.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn93@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676326_f35975311b89dc7b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Xianbing-Wrapper-Dough.jpeg/728px-Xianbing-Wrapper-Dough.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn10@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673341_1828601185d1ffca.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Make-Bing-Step-14.jpg/aid11760819-v4-728px-Make-Bing-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn98@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672258_5c627a8fe155eeb6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Rolling-Dough-Out.jpeg/728px-Rolling-Dough-Out.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn77@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675528_b6a739475924c950.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Twisting-Wrapper-Into-Xianbing.jpeg/728px-Twisting-Wrapper-Into-Xianbing.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn5@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109677265_d4474256ac5ab7c5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Xianbing-Almost-Done.jpeg/728px-Xianbing-Almost-Done.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn18@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109673365_9f80db7d6743e629.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Season Summer Squash","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-Summer-Squash","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Summer squash includes varieties like zucchini, pattypan, crookneck, and zephyr squash. It's easy to cook and tastes great with just a couple of added ingredients. Season summer squash quickly with spices and herbs like parsley, salt, and pepper, or add ingredients like garlic or parmesan cheese for additional flavor. Feel free to get creative with your squash seasoning and try out different combinations!\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using Fresh Herbs and Spices\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Fresh-Herbs-and-Spices\">Using Fresh Herbs and Spices</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Add fresh parsley, mint, and thyme to cooked squash for a mix of flavors. Season cooked summer squash with  each of fresh parsley, mint, and thyme. Do this by either measuring the herbs into a bowl and tossing the cooked squash in it or sprinkling a little seasoning on the individual cooked slices. Sprinkle a little salt and pepper onto the summer squash too.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season Summer Squash Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Use  of each fresh herb for 2 medium squash.</li>\n<li>If you don't have fresh herbs, use  of dried herbs for every  of each ingredient.</li>\n<li>This recipe is made by seasoning the squash after it's been cooked already, but you can try seasoning it beforehand if you'd like.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use salt, pepper, and fresh parsley for a quick and easy seasoning. Cook summer squash in a pan and add salt and pepper to taste. Chop up fresh parsley so that you have  and add this to the squash. Mix everything together so it’s well combined before serving it.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>of chopped parsley works well for 2 squash.</li>\n<li>Use  of dried parsley instead of  of fresh parsley, if needed.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Combine chives or scallions with summer squash for an onion flavor. Cut up the herbs so you have  of chopped chives or 2 scallions. Add the chives or scallions in with sautéed summer squash, stirring it so it’s thoroughly seasoned before serving.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-Summer-Squash-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season Summer Squash Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-3.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This recipe calls for the squash to be mostly cooked before it's seasoned, with the chives or scallions added in towards the end.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Mix fresh dill with olive oil to rub it onto your summer squash. Chop up 2.5 summer squash into slices of whatever thickness you prefer. Cut up enough dill so that you have  of it when it’s chopped. Spread the squash slices out and sprinkle olive oil over them so they’re lightly coated. Add the dill on top of the squash and stir them all together so the dill is well distributed. Cook or grill the squash, and it’s ready to eat!<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You could also mix the chopped dill and olive oil together and then use a basting brush to apply the mixture to the summer squash.</li>\n<li>If you don't have fresh dill, use  of dried dill instead.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Stir fresh basil leaves into cooked squash for a refreshing taste. Cook your summer squash in olive oil, adding in things like garlic and salt if you’d like. Chop up fresh basil leaves with a sharp knife and add them into the cooked squash. Stir the squash so the basil is mixed in well before eating it.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You might use 10 to 15 basil leaves for  of summer squash (or  of dried basil).</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Adding Other Foods for Flavor\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adding-Other-Foods-for-Flavor\">Adding Other Foods for Flavor</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Top the summer squash with bread crumbs and parmesan for a savory taste. Cut up your summer squash into thick slices and drizzle a light layer of olive oil over them. Mix  of Parmesan cheese with  of breadcrumbs in a bowl, as well as enough salt and pepper depending on your taste preferences. Spread the squash out and sprinkle the breadcrumb mixture over the slices, topping them all evenly before baking the squash.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-Summer-Squash-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season Summer Squash Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-6.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This recipe calls for  of summer squash.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Create a marinade by using vinegar, lemon juice, garlic, and thyme. Mix  of white wine vinegar,  of lemon juice, 1 tablespoon (8.4 g) of minced garlic, and 2 teaspoons (1.8 g) of chopped thyme leaves in a bowl together. Stir in some salt and pepper and add  of sliced summer squash. Toss the squash so it’s seasoned well and pour all of the ingredients into a pan. Let the squash sit in the marinade for about 3 hours to 1 day.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>The squash can sit in the marinade at room temperature for up to 3 hours, but if you’re marinating the squash for a full day, place the pan in the fridge and cover it.</li>\n<li>Cook the summer squash once it has soaked in the marinade.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Saute the squash in onion and garlic for a stronger flavor. Chop up 3 squash so they're in slices and cook 1 small chopped onion in an oiled pan until it’s soft. Add the squash to the pan and cook them for about 8 minutes or until they have brown spots on them. Place 2 cloves of minced garlic to the pan and mash it into the pan as it cooks. Stir all of the ingredients together and add a little parsley, salt, and pepper depending on your taste preferences.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-Summer-Squash-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season Summer Squash Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-8.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Combine your squash with chopped jalapeno, garlic, and red pepper for a spicy taste. Cut up a jalapeno pepper and cook it in a pan until it’s slightly browned. Add in 2 cloves of sliced garlic and  of crushed red pepper flakes to the pan, stirring the ingredients together as they cook. Put  of sliced summer squash into the pan and saute them until they’re soft and slightly browned too.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-Summer-Squash-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season Summer Squash Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fd/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-9.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Sprinkle a little bit of lime juice over the squash for added taste, if you’d like.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you don't want to add too many seasonings to your summer squash, it's always okay to just stick with salt and pepper.</li>\n<li>Ground cumin or coriander are also good on summer squash.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Avoid using as much dried herb as you would a fresh herb—dried herbs tend to have a stronger flavor.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-Summer-Squash&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.foodandwine.com/recipes/sauteed-yellow-squash-fresh-herbs\">https://www.foodandwine.com/recipes/sauteed-yellow-squash-fresh-herbs</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/rachael-ray/sauteed-yellow-squash-recipe-1915659\">https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/rachael-ray/sauteed-yellow-squash-recipe-1915659</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/rachael-ray/sauteed-yellow-squash-recipe-1915659\">https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/rachael-ray/sauteed-yellow-squash-recipe-1915659</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/summer-squash-recipe-1944670\">https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/summer-squash-recipe-1944670</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2017/09/stewed-summer-squash-recipe.html\">https://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2017/09/stewed-summer-squash-recipe.html</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.thekitchn.com/recipe-baked-summer-squash-recipes-from-the-kitchn-60018\">https://www.thekitchn.com/recipe-baked-summer-squash-recipes-from-the-kitchn-60018</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/giada-de-laurentiis/marinated-zucchini-and-summer-squash-recipe-1942989\">https://www.foodnetwork.com/recipes/giada-de-laurentiis/marinated-zucchini-and-summer-squash-recipe-1942989</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.food.com/recipe/sauteed-summer-squash-cooks-illustrated-460380\">https://www.food.com/recipe/sauteed-summer-squash-cooks-illustrated-460380</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/summer-squash-saute-51169540\">https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/summer-squash-saute-51169540</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"e425fa3559a3eaeb8f6e10f81c5009e8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662553_bb70d76d1c82cc96.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662553_bb70d76d1c82cc96.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-3.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn97@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109675735_902dbfc519354cf4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-6.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn33@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109670942_31b8917605783889.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-8.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn78@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673945_73f7f4858069d02d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fd/Season-Summer-Squash-Step-9.jpg/aid11892904-v4-728px-Season-Summer-Squash-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn38@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673438_224916ed8d1b0d09.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Focus a Camera","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Focus-a-Camera","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>While automatic focus usually does the job, sometimes focusing manually is the key to a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Take-Better-Photographs\" title=\"Take Better Photographs\">great photograph</a>. For a DSLR or SLR camera, set the lens to manual focus, then twist the focus ring until the subject becomes sharp. If you want a focused subject and <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Blur-the-Background-of-a-Photograph\" title=\"Blur the Background of a Photograph\">blurred background</a>, use techniques to achieve a shallow depth of field. For better smartphone photographs, tap the screen to manually focus, and try to keep your phone completely still.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using Manual Focus on a DSLR\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Manual-Focus-on-a-DSLR\">Using Manual Focus on a DSLR</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Flip the switch on your lens to “MF.” Check the side of your DSLR (digital single-lens reflex) or SLR lens for a small switch labeled “AF - MF” or “A - M.” If the switch is set to “AF,” or automatic focus,” flip it to “MF,” or manual focus.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>While you're getting used to shooting in manual, try photographing still subjects, like flowers or other objects. It will be a lot harder to focus manually if you're shooting moving objects or people.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n<li>When set to automatic focus, depressing the shutter button halfway automatically adjusts the focus. In manual mode, you’ll rotate the focus ring on the lens.</li>\n<li>Be sure to switch your camera to manual focus before twisting the focus ring. Adjusting the focusing ring while the camera is in automatic focus may damage the lens.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Twist the focus ring until your subject is sharp. You’ll find 2 rings around a DSLR zoom lens. The one closest to the camera’s body controls zoom, and the one toward the end of the lens controls focus. Peer into the viewfinder, twist the focus ring, and watch different parts of the shot come into focus.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Focus-a-Camera-Step-2.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Play with the focus function as you observe how the shot changes to get a feel for manual adjustment.</li>\n<li>Look for 2 scales of numbers labeled “ft” and “m” around the focus ring. The number displayed through the viewing window or aligned with a mark tells you where the lens is focusing. If you see 1.25 on the viewer or aligned with an arrow, objects  away from the lens are in focus.</li>\n<li>When you're focusing on your subject, try to make sure the focus is on their eyes, so their eyes appear nice and clear. Then, you can create different looks by adjusting the aperture.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n<li>If you use a wide aperture, you can create a soft focus in the background. That way, the subject will still be in focus, but the background behind them will be blurred.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Use live view mode to fine tune the focus. The viewfinder, or the small window that you look through while taking a photograph, doesn’t always offer the best representation of focus. If your camera has an LCD screen, switch to live view mode to do a final focus check. Watch your shot on the LCD screen, and twist the focus ring until your subject becomes sharp.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Focus-a-Camera-Step-3.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Most photographers prefer to look through the viewfinder when they take photographs. Holding the camera to your face braces it and minimizes movement. You can still take the photograph using the viewfinder, but use the LCD screen to adjust your focus.</li>\n<li>Note that once you’ve set the focus, you must keep the camera that distance away from the subject. The subject will become unfocused if it moves outside the range noted on the focus ring. For this reason, autofocus is best for moving objects.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Measure the distance from a still subject to the lens for perfect focus. Recall that the numbers on the focus ring tell you where the lens is focusing. For perfect focus, set your focus distance, then position your subject exactly that distance from the lens.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Focus-a-Camera-Step-4.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>For instance, if you’re taking a portrait, place the camera on a tripod, set your focus to , and position the sitter exactly that distance from the camera lens.</li>\n<li>Measuring works well in a studio setting with still objects, but it probably won’t be an option if you’re shooting in the field. When you can’t make an exact measurement, estimate the distance and adjust the focus using the LCD screen.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Adjusting the Depth of Field\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adjusting-the-Depth-of-Field\">Adjusting the Depth of Field</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Check your camera’s minimum focus distance. The minimum focus distance is how far the lens must be from a subject at full zoom. If you want the subject to be in sharp focus with a blurred background, you’ll need to get as close to the object as possible in full zoom. Search online for your camera or lens model number along with the keywords “minimum focus distance.”<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Focus-a-Camera-Step-5.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Your DSLR probably came with a basic kit lens, such as an 18-105 mm with a minimum focus distance of . This means it can’t focus on objects closer than  at full zoom.</li>\n<li>A good macro lens, which is intended for highly detailed close-ups, can focus on objects  or less from the lens at full zoom.</li>\n<li>Point-and-shoot cameras with optical zoom also have minimum focus distances. If you don’t have a DSLR, you can still manipulate the depth of field to achieve a sharply focused subject with a blurred background.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Zoom in on your subject for a shallow depth of field. With your lens at full zoom, position your subject at the minimum focus distance from the tip of the lens. If your minimum focus distance is , the subject should be that far away from the lens.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Focus-a-Camera-Step-6.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Depth of field is the amount of the photograph that appears sharp from the foreground to background. When a photograph is taken at a shallow depth of field, an object closer to the lens appears in sharp focus, and the background is blurred.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use the largest aperture setting to blur the background. The aperture setting, or the f-stop number, controls the amount of light that enters the lens. A smaller f-stop number, such as f2, corresponds with a larger aperture. A larger aperture results in a shallow depth of field, which yields a sharply focused subject and blurred background.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Focus-a-Camera-Step-7.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Look for a dial on the top of your camera. Set it to “A” or “Av,” which denotes aperture priority mode. In this mode, you set the aperture, and the camera automatically sets shutter speed. In “M,” or manual mode, you select both the aperture and shutter speed.</li>\n<li>If you have a point-and-shoot camera, you might be able to manually control the aperture, but not all models offer this feature. If you can’t, you should still be able to achieve a shallow depth of field by zooming all the way in at the minimum focus distance.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Put distance between your subject and the background. The more space there is between the subject and background, the blurrier the background will be. Keep as much distance as possible between the subject you’re focusing on and any objects in the background.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Focus-a-Camera-Step-8.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>For instance, photographing a flower at least  in front of background objects will give you more blur than if there are objects  behind it.</li>\n<li>This principle also applies to smartphone cameras. To a degree, you can achieve the effects of a shallow depth of field, even though phone cameras don’t have optical zoom.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Adjust the shutter speed and ISO, if necessary. A larger aperture means more light enters the lens. This could produce bright, noisy photographs in outdoor settings or other well-lit locations. To decrease brightness while retaining a large aperture, you’ll need to adjust the shutter speed and ISO settings.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Focus-a-Camera-Step-9.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Go with a faster shutter speed to decrease brightness. If the current setting is 200, this means the shutter speed is 1/200 of a second. Try incrementally faster shutter speeds, such as 1/500 or 1/1000, until you achieve your desired brightness.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Make sure your ISO is set to 100 or 200. In well-lit conditions, higher ISO settings will produce grainy, noisy photographs.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n<li>The exact methods for setting shutter speed and ISO vary by camera model, so look through your menu options or check your user manual for specific instructions.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Focusing a Smartphone Camera\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Focusing-a-Smartphone-Camera\">Focusing a Smartphone Camera</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Tap the screen where you want the camera to focus. To manually focus a smartphone, simply tap on the object as it appears on the screen. You’ll then see a square or rectangle on the object.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Focus-a-Camera-Step-10.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Press and hold the screen to lock the focus on your subject. This means if other objects in the frame change position, your phone will stay focused where you’ve selected.</li>\n<li>Note that the subject you’ve locked focus on needs to stay put, or it’ll become unfocused. Additionally, keep your phone the same distance from the subject after setting the focus. Don’t bring it closer to or farther away from the subject, or you’ll lose focus.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Keep your phone as still as possible. Unsteady hands are the number 1 reason for blurry cell phone photographs. To guarantee your phone remains still, invest in a tripod designed for smartphones.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Focus-a-Camera-Step-11.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you don’t have a tripod handy, try bracing the phone on a surface. If you have to hold it in the air, try to keep your arms as close to your body as possible. Hold your breath while taking the photograph, or do your best to slow your breathing.</li>\n<li>Good lighting can also reduce blur due to shaking. In lower light, the shutter speed is slower, which leaves more time for shaking to blur the image.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Avoid using digital zoom. For DSLR and point-and-shoot cameras, optical zoom is when the lens physically moves to enlarge the subject. Cell phone cameras don’t currently have this feature. A smartphone's zoom function simply crops and digitally enlarges the shot, which lowers image quality.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Focus-a-Camera-Step-12.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Instead of using digital zoom, bring the camera’s lens as close to the subject as possible. Keep in mind most smartphone cameras can’t focus on objects less than  from the lens.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Use distance to blur the background. As with DSLR and point-and-shoot cameras, you can manipulate a smartphone camera’s depth of field to blur backgrounds. Tap the screen to manually focus on your subject, and put as much space as possible between it and any objects in the background.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Focus-a-Camera-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Focus a Camera Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Focus-a-Camera-Step-13.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Check your smartphone camera settings for macro or portrait modes. In these modes, you’ll have an easier time achieving a sharply focused subject with a blurred background.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Play around with your camera’s settings. Manually adjusting settings might seem intimidating at first but, with a little tinkering, it’ll become intuitive.</li>\n<li>Android and iPhone default camera apps only allow you to manually adjust a few settings. If you want more control over your smartphone camera, you can always download a third-party app.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2>\n<ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Almost-Any-35mm-Film-Camera\" title=\"Use Almost Any 35mm Film Camera\">Use Almost Any 35mm Film Camera</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Every-Nikon-Digital-SLR\" title=\"Use Every Nikon Digital SLR\">Use Every Nikon Digital SLR</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Blur-the-Background-of-a-Photograph\" title=\"Blur the Background of a Photograph\">Blur the Background of a Photograph</a></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Focus-a-Camera&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://photographylife.com/what-is-shutter-speed-in-photography\">https://photographylife.com/what-is-shutter-speed-in-photography</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://photographylife.com/what-is-iso-in-photography\">https://photographylife.com/what-is-iso-in-photography</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\"
