<span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://iphonephotographyschool.com/focus-tips/\">https://iphonephotographyschool.com/focus-tips/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-22\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/portrait-mode-photos-tips-tricks-google-2017-11#3-dont-stand-too-close-to-the-background-3\">https://www.businessinsider.com/portrait-mode-photos-tips-tricks-google-2017-11#3-dont-stand-too-close-to-the-background-3</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-23\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2383739,00.asp\">https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2383739,00.asp</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"8cb1b464f5a155b25994a1f7c2993c7e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn67@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662204_501bb910d72bc3e6.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn67@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662204_501bb910d72bc3e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Focus-a-Camera-Step-2.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn29@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109674373_03831ee6ecf9cdcf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Focus-a-Camera-Step-3.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn89@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109677152_2cc22dfdd131e2c1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Focus-a-Camera-Step-4.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn17@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109676495_4d7e8cd0b0111588.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Focus-a-Camera-Step-5.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn81@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109675590_253dd76a61931197.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Focus-a-Camera-Step-6.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn90@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109671102_65f02b74e75b6e40.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Focus-a-Camera-Step-7.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn53@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109675958_3ecbbad025130b11.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Focus-a-Camera-Step-8.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn33@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672452_1f3953d93b3db73f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Focus-a-Camera-Step-9.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn73@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109676163_9aa435984f88e6a6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Focus-a-Camera-Step-10.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn37@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109674463_72341a57634528d7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Focus-a-Camera-Step-11.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn45@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109674421_633990b596b92c15.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Focus-a-Camera-Step-12.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn66@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672204_24b3da9132b56512.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Focus-a-Camera-Step-13.jpg/aid656578-v4-728px-Focus-a-Camera-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn33@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676562_3a678359036dbe36.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Hold Chopsticks","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Hold-Chopsticks","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Chopsticks have been the go-to dining utensil in East Asia for thousands of years, thanks to their simplicity and versatility. If you’re used to using forks and knives to manipulate your food, you may have a tough time getting the hang of chopsticks at first. Once you understand the right way to hold them, however, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Eat-with-Chopsticks\" title=\"Eat with Chopsticks\">mastering the mechanics</a> becomes much easier. Start by resting the first chopstick along the inner edge of your ring finger and the webbing of your thumb on your dominant hand. Place the second one between your index finger, middle finger, and thumb, the way you would hold a pencil. This will allow you to move the top chopstick freely while keeping the bottom one fixed in place.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Positioning the Chopsticks Correctly\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Positioning-the-Chopsticks-Correctly\">Positioning the Chopsticks Correctly</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Pick up the chopsticks with your dominant hand. Use whichever hand you’re more coordinated with to pluck the chopsticks up from the table, with the back of your hand facing you. Place your non-dominant hand beneath the tip end of the chopsticks and squeeze them together gently. This will line them up so that they’re perfectly parallel with one another.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>On a standard table setting, your chopsticks will be lying side-by-side in front of you at a horizontal angle.</li>\n<li>It’s usually easiest to pick up your chopsticks using your first 2 or 3 fingers and thumb.</li>\n<li>Be careful not to let the chopsticks clack together loudly as you pick them up. Doing so might be considered rude in quiet eateries and more formal settings.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place your hand right around the top third of the chopsticks. Use your non-dominant hand to steady the chopsticks as you adjust the placement of your dominant hand. Hold both chopsticks together in the crook between the base of your thumb and index finger until you’re ready to dig in.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you’re not sure exactly where to place your hand, align the top of the chopsticks with the tip of your thumb, then turn your hand over and grip the point nearest to the base of your thumb.</li>\n<li>Having your hand too high or too low on the chopsticks will make it harder to manipulate them properly.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Rest the lower chopstick across the base of your thumb and ring finger. Arrange your first chopstick so that the upper part is nestled in the crevice between your thumb and forefinger and the tip end is lying against the inner edge of your ring finger. Once you’ve got this chopstick where you want it, avoid moving or adjusting it.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Some native chopstick users prefer to place their bottom chopstick a little higher up on the hand, right around the base of the forefinger.</li>\n<li>When used correctly, the bottom chopstick should remain stationary, allowing the top chopstick to do all the work.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Grip the upper chopstick between your index finger, middle finger, and thumb. Now, take the second chopstick and shift it between the top first knuckles of your index and middle fingers. Brace the inner edge of the chopstick with the pad of your thumb.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Make sure both chopsticks are pointing in the same direction, with the tips and top ends evenly aligned.</li>\n<li>This hand position should feel similar to the one that most people use to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hold-a-Pencil\" title=\"Hold a Pencil\">hold a pencil</a>.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Keep your thumb from moving as much as possible. Use the top of your thumb as a fulcrum for the upper chopstick, providing just enough counter-pressure for it to rotate against. The base is there to cradle the lower chopstick and nothing more. Attempting to incorporate your thumb into the movement will just make you more likely to trip yourself up.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>It’s also important to keep your thumb straight, rather than allowing it to bend at the knuckle.</li>\n<li>Making sure your thumb stays put may seem complicated, but in reality, it gives you one less thing to worry about and lets you focus your attention on working the chopsticks open and closed.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Controlling Your Chopsticks\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Controlling-Your-Chopsticks\">Controlling Your Chopsticks</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Open and close the chopsticks with your first two fingers. To open the chopsticks, lift your index and middle fingers in unison. To close them, simply press down again. The chopstick should feel like an extension of both fingers.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you’re having trouble picking up food this way, try adjusting your grip slightly so that the pad of your middle finger is bracing the bottom chopstick on the opposite side of your thumb.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Only the tips of the chopsticks should move. The tops should stay where they are, or come slightly closer to each other without actually touching.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Keep a firm grip on both chopsticks to keep them from shifting. If necessary, pause for a moment and use your non-dominant hand to reset both chopsticks, remembering to lay the bottom one across your ring finger and the base of your thumb and keep the top one poised like a pencil. The further up or down your chopsticks slide, the more difficult it will become to use them.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Hold your chopsticks securely, but don’t squeeze them. This will just tire out your hand and cause your technique to deteriorate.</li>\n<li>Wooden and bamboo chopsticks tend to be better for beginners, since they offer a little more traction against your hand and one another.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Maintain gentle pressure on the top chopstick to hold onto your food. Open your chopsticks and clamp them down on a bite-sized piece of whatever you're eating. As you raise the bite to your mouth, concentrate on pressing down lightly on the upper chopstick. This will keep the food pinned between the top and bottom chopsticks, ensuring that it doesn't go anywhere.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Like anything else, becoming proficient with chopsticks just takes practice. Try moving foods of various shapes, sizes, and textures from one bowl to another slowly. This fun exercise will help you get the fundamentals down.</li>\n<li>Remember, the bottom chopstick is just there to provide support from beneath. The top chopstick is the one that should be doing all of the work.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Reverse the opening-closing motion to tear food into smaller pieces. Bring the tips of your chopsticks together and stick them into broadest part of the food. Then, pull them apart with enough force to separate the food into two pieces. Keep in mind that this alternative \"cutting\" method will only work on softer varieties of food.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Traditional Asian dishes typically contain meats, vegetables, and grains that have already been reduced to a size suitable for chopsticks. Certain foods like tempura and whole fish, however, may need to be broken up in order to be made more manageable.</li>\n<li>In casual dining settings, it's also usually acceptable to take bites off of large pieces of food rather than tearing or cutting them.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Learning Proper Chopstick Etiquette\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Learning-Proper-Chopstick-Etiquette\">Learning Proper Chopstick Etiquette</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Never stick your chopsticks straight up in a bowl of rice. This may seem like a harmless way of getting them to stay put, but it’s a cardinal sin when it comes to chopstick use in Japan and many other Asian countries. The reason for this is because at Japanese funeral ceremonies, it’s customary for the family of the deceased to place a pair of chopsticks vertically in a bowl of rice and leave it as an offering to the spirit of their departed loved one.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you are to let go of your chopsticks, place them horizontally above your bowl so it stays still.</li>\n<li>Since behaviors that remind your hosts or the people around you of death are thought to bring bad luck, they’re sure to put a damper on the mood of the meal.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Always use both chopsticks at the same time. Resist the urge to push your food around or spear stubborn bites with the point of one of your chopsticks, no matter how much difficulty you’re having getting used to them. Chopsticks come in pairs for a reason. They’re meant to be used for picking up food and nothing more.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>In some countries, even holding your chopsticks separately in different hands is considered a faux pas.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Avoid laying your chopsticks across your plate or bowl unless you’re done, especially at formal meals or restaurants. You might want to put down your chopsticks for many reasons, such as getting a glass of water. Many restaurants provide chopstick rests so that their diners can set their chopsticks down when they’re not using them. you<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 12 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>When you’re at formal meals, putting down your chopsticks might be a symbol that you’re no longer hungry and roll off a dish. Unless your at a formal restaurant or meeting, it’s mostly alright to put down your chopsticks.</li>\n<li>This doesn’t mean you should put down your chopsticks. It’s alright to do it occasionally, but try to hold it up for the most part.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Try not to gesture with your chopsticks or point them at other people. If you have a tendency to talk with your hands or feel the need to act out something you’re saying, be sure to put down your chopsticks before doing so. Imagine how you would feel if someone were to jab a fork at you while making a point!<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 13 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This should go without saying, but it’s also a pretty big no-no to drum on the table, conduct an invisible symphony, imitate a walrus, or act out a mock sword fight with your chopsticks. Remember, they’re tools, not toys.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Move dishes with your hands, not your chopsticks. When you need to rearrange plates, bowls, or other dining ware, use your free hand rather than scooting or dragging the items across the table with your chopsticks. Otherwise, you risk insulting your hosts by using their utensils for something other than their intended purpose.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you need to pass or relocate an especially large, heavy, or cumbersome dish, play it safe and set your chopsticks down so you can use both hands.</li>\n<li>In China and some other Asian countries, banging bowls with chopsticks is a behavior associated with beggars, which means you’ll also inadvertently be dealing a blow to your own dignity.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Don’t eat or take food from the serving dish with your personal chopsticks if you are being offered serving chopsticks. Move the food to your plate with the serving chopsticks or other serving utensils provided. Then, use your own chopsticks to eat from your own dish. That way, you won’t have touched everyone else’s food with utensils that have been in your mouth.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hold-Chopsticks-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hold Chopsticks Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Another blunder to watch out for while serving yourself is digging around in the serving dish for the best looking pieces or your favorite ingredients. That’s just selfish.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Sticking your chopsticks in a communal dish is unsanitary, as it increases the risk of cross-contamination, but it may also come across as disrespectful if your fellow diners don’t know that you aren’t aware of the rule.</li>\n<li>In many places, serving chopsticks will not be provided. You are allowed to use your own chopsticks in this case.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>To determine what size chopsticks are best suited for your hand, measure the distance between your outstretched thumb and forefinger in centimeters, then multiply this measurement by 1.5. The number you get will tell you how long your ideal chopsticks should be, which could make practicing easier.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup></li>\n<li>If you just can’t hold onto anything to save your life, consider swallowing your pride and picking up a pair of trainer chopsticks, which are connected at the top by a small plastic joint. Eating a few meals with these will give you a feel for the motion that the upper chopstick is supposed to make.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup></li>\n<li>In Japan, it's customary to hold chopsticks with your right hand, even if you happen to be left-handed.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you’re planning a visit to a place where chopsticks are the utensil of choice, it’s a good idea to familiarize yourself with other points of etiquette and taboos related to the use of chopsticks to avoid offending your hosts or the other diners around you.</li>\n<li>Smooth, round chopsticks like those made from plastic or metal are especially prone to rolling, sliding, and crossing over one another, so watch out.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hold-Chopsticks&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap id=\"_note-22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-22\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-23\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"#_ref-24\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://eatingoutloud.com/2010/05/chopstick-selection-for-chopstick-virgins.html\">https://eatingoutloud.com/2010/05/chopstick-selection-for-chopstick-virgins.html</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"477ab8e86df381264f9d2834340ddd76","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662865_6a1b7bdc94c19aaf.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn51@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662865_6a1b7bdc94c19aaf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn65@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109676989_35d6bab37d0a3586.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn9@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109672289_71868432064521bb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn85@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109674949_5febed8854afa6cd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1d/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn1@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675729_5e62f34b44431b0c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn49@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676100_d5101ed088717f22.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2e/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-13-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn25@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109674321_b62dcea5ef966284.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Hold-Chopsticks-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2729084-v4-728px-Hold-Chopsticks-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn81@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109673228_102a313d974cbab1.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Diagnose Food Intolerance","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Having a food intolerance can be hard to diagnose, especially if you're not sure if it's an intolerance or allergy. Pay close attention to your symptoms that might indicate that you have an allergy or intolerance, and then see your doctor.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Keep a food diary and talk to your doctor about an elimination diet to pinpoint your diagnosis.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Diagnose-Food-Intolerance&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Diagnose-Food-Intolerance&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Comparing Food Allergy and Intolerance Symptoms\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Comparing-Food-Allergy-and-Intolerance-Symptoms\">Comparing Food Allergy and Intolerance Symptoms</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Pay attention to the timing of your symptoms. If you have a food intolerance, you may not see a reaction to the food you eat right away. A food allergy will result in a more immediate reaction.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Digestive symptoms caused by a food intolerance usually come on gradually over the course of a couple of hours.</li>\n<li>A food allergy usually results in symptoms almost immediately.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Be on the lookout for stomach pain for food intolerance. If your stomach pain is related to a food intolerance, it will come a few hours after you eat the food. The pain can be mild or severe, depending on how much of the food you ate and how severe your intolerance is.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-2.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This stomach pain may also include heartburn. Heartburn is a burning sensation near the top of your stomach or in your throat.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Look for bloating, excess gas, or diarrhea. If you develop bloating, gas, or diarrhea a few hours after eating, chances are you're intolerant of one of the foods you ate. If you develop these symptoms more than 2 or 3 hours after you ate, they are likely caused by something else.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-3.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Diarrhea is usually considered a severe symptom. If a type of food triggers diarrhea, you may have a serious intolerance or allergy.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Keep an eye on how much food you can eat. If you have a food intolerance, you might be able to eat small amounts of the offending foods without symptoms. If you have a food allergy, you won't be able to eat any of the food you're allergic to without having a reaction.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-4.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Look for rashes or itchy skin for evidence of food allergies. Rashes or itchy skin usually indicate a food allergy, rather than an intolerance. You will rarely experience these symptoms as a result of an intolerance.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-5.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you notice that certain foods seem to cause rashes, swelling in your mouth or throat, or hives, see your doctor immediately. These are symptoms of an allergic reaction, can be severe, and might need immediate treatment.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Diagnose-Food-Intolerance&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Keeping a Food Diary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Keeping-a-Food-Diary\">Keeping a Food Diary</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Divide your diary into individual days. It's important to track what you're eating every single day. You might not eat the foods you're intolerant of every single day and you might be intolerant of more than 1 food. Keeping your diary every day can help you detect a pattern.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-6.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Track every single food you eat. As you keep your diary, make sure you write down all the food you eat. This includes regular meals, snacks, desserts, and anything you drink. Even if you eat just a small amount of food, you should still track it.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-7.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can use food diary apps if you have a smartphone. It's an easy way to track everything without having to carry a notebook and pencil with you. There are also websites you can use to track your food.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Write down any symptoms that develop. After you've written down each meal or snack, write down any symptoms that you develop after eating. It's important that you write them down as soon as they develop. It makes it easier to see which foods might be causing the symptoms.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-8.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Make sure you note times for your meals and symptoms. Make sure you write down what time you ate each food, and what time you developed symptoms. It makes it easier for you and your doctor to see which foods might be causing your symptoms.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-9.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Diagnose-Food-Intolerance&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Ruling Out Allergies and Eliminating Foods\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ruling-Out-Allergies-and-Eliminating-Foods\">Ruling Out Allergies and Eliminating Foods</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Review your food diary for likely causes. Once you've been keeping your food diary for a couple of weeks, look it over. If you see a pattern where you eat certain foods and then develop symptoms a few hours later, write those foods down. Those are likely the foods that your body is intolerant of, and they're a good place to start when diagnosing your food intolerance.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-10.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Talk to a dietitian or your doctor. Before you begin an elimination diet, you should speak to a dietitian or your doctor. Make sure you bring your food diary with you and your list of suspect foods.  Your doctor or dietitian can help you narrow down which food and drinks to avoid, how to read food labels, how long your diet should last, and if you need to supplement your diet with alternative forms of nutrition.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-11.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Undergo allergy testing. If it's not clear to your doctor where you have an allergy or intolerance (some food allergies can be mild enough to be mistaken for intolerance), they may recommend an allergy test. There are 2 types of tests. Your doctor will choose the best one for your condition.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-12.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If your allergies seem severe or developed quickly, your doctor will order a skin-prick or blood test.</li>\n<li>If your allergies are mild or your doctor is unsure whether you have an allergy, your doctor may suggest an elimination diet instead.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Cut suspected foods from your diet for 2 to 6 weeks to test for intolerance or mild allergies. Removing all of the foods you suspect of making you sick lets you reintroduce them slowly later. Cut all of the foods on your list from your diet and keep them out of your diet for 2 to 6 weeks. If your symptoms improve, one of those foods is likely what's causing your symptoms.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-13.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Your doctor will tell you exactly how long your diet should last.</li>\n<li>Make sure you're noting in your food diary which foods you're cutting and when and if you develop symptoms again.</li>\n<li>If your symptoms don't disappear, see your doctor.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup> Your symptoms might be caused by something else, or you may have missed a pattern in your food diary. Your doctor can help you figure out the next steps.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Reintroduce the foods you cut. Once your symptoms have subsided, you can start reintroducing the foods you cut from your diet. Reintroduce them one at a time for a week or so. If your symptoms don't reappear, reintroduce another food. If your symptoms do return, the food you reintroduced more recently is likely the food causing your symptoms.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-14.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Your doctor should tell you which foods to reintroduce when.</li>\n<li>Keep tracking your intake in your food diary. It will help you see exactly which foods cause the symptoms to reappear.</li></ul></li>\n<li>See your doctor again. Once you've completed your diet, your doctor will likely want to see you again. Make a follow-up appointment once you've completed your elimination diet, taking your food diary with you. Your doctor should be able to then diagnose which foods are causing your symptoms.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Diagnose Food Intolerance Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-15.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Diagnose-Food-Intolerance&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-14\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-allergy/diagnosis/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-allergy/diagnosis/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-15\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-allergy/diagnosis/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-allergy/diagnosis/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161208_b01]. 9 December 2019.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-17\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-18\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161208_b01]. 9 December 2019.</span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/food-intolerance/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"bc92be38bc570512d7b185dd4fa6a5b3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn55@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662915_9d7bb5fb2fd92d4a.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b5/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn55@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662915_9d7bb5fb2fd92d4a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-2.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn1@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109670979_f6caaeb3afff11d5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-3.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn85@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109675615_9d5a3d2a5afa9377.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-4.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn14@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673367_ded8c709cbd3e7bc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-5.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn38@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109672065_c79a3df6144e255b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-6.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn17@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672461_d5c48717f40812d6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-7.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn5@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674711_b1e77bed05b4730b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-8.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn81@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109671190_2b334c9065097d49.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-9.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn90@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672327_a1a75507287cae5a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-10.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn85@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673297_e91f7a41486d8dc3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-11.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn50@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109672118_0a25964ad7d20ffd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-12.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn21@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674423_1c60967f0f931571.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-13.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn73@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675411_52fb652c964b7936.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7b/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-14.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn82@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109670861_8bb61aeeb7ff2cf8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-15.jpg/aid9707198-v4-728px-Diagnose-Food-Intolerance-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn21@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109675937_f0148f506f19e50a.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Roast Garlic","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Roast-Garlic","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Roasted garlic, which is less bitter than raw garlic, is a deliciously fragrant addition to any dish. Wrap a whole head in foil to roast it in the oven or, if you want a faster option, toss pre-peeled cloves in a skillet with olive oil. When you're finished, use your garlic in sauces, soups, and dips to make them even more flavorful.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Oven-Roasted Garlic\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Oven-Roasted-Garlic\">Oven-Roasted Garlic</span></h3>\n<ul><li>1 head of garlic</li>\n<li>of olive oil</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Stove-Roasted Garlic\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stove-Roasted-Garlic\">Stove-Roasted Garlic</span></h3>\n<ul><li>25 to 30 peeled cloves of garlic</li>\n<li>of olive oil</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Making Oven-Roasted Garlic in the Oven\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Oven-Roasted-Garlic-in-the-Oven\">Making Oven-Roasted Garlic in the Oven</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Preheat the oven to . An oven usually takes about 20 to 30 minutes to heat up. Turn it on while you prepare the garlic so it’s at the right temperature when you’re ready to put the garlic in.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>To speed up the preheating, you can set the oven to the broil setting first, which uses the top burner inside the oven to create direct, intense heat. Turn the oven to the correct temperature before you cook your garlic.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Peel off the papery layer of the garlic, leaving the skin intact. Garlic cloves have very thin outer layers that are a texture similar to tissue paper. Gently remove these layers with your hands, stopping when you reach the skin of the cloves.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you also peel off the skin, the head will fall apart. Leave the skin on so the garlic stays intact.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Cut about  off the top of the head. Use a sharp paring knife to slice cleanly through the garlic on a cutting board. Trim off just enough that the cloves are exposed.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you don’t see the tops of the cloves, cut off another . Continue trimming until the cloves are visible.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Set the head on a piece of aluminum foil that’s big enough to cover it. Tear off a sheet of foil and smooth it out on a flat surface. Center the head of garlic on top, with the exposed cloves facing up.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can tear pieces from a roll of foil or use precut sheets of aluminum foil, which are found at most kitchen stores or from an online retailer.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Drizzle  of olive oil over the top of the head. Be sure to sprinkle oil on each of the exposed cloves, so they can soak up the flavor and moisture. Move your hand back and forth above the head as you drizzle the oil to avoid pouring too much in 1 section.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>For more control when applying the olive oil, attach an oil pourer onto the open end of your bottle.</li>\n<li>You can substitute any type of cooking oil for the olive oil, based on your taste preferences.</li>\n<li>If you want to season your garlic, sprinkle on sea salt or the spices of your choice after drizzling the oil.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Wrap the head in aluminum foil. With the garlic in the middle of the sheet, pull the foil up snugly around the sides of the head. Then crimp the edges of the foil together in the center, checking to make sure there are no gaps where the garlic is exposed. Cover the head completely.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you accidentally rip or puncture the foil when you’re folding it, start over with a fresh sheet so there are no holes.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place the wrapped head in the oven to roast for 40 minutes. Set the foil directly on the oven rack so that the folded edge at the top of the head is pointing up. The best spot for the garlic is the middle rack, where the hot air can circulate around the entire head, allowing it to cook evenly.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Use a kitchen timer or the clock app on your phone to keep track of the time.</li>\n<li>You can also place the wrapped garlic on a baking sheet or in the cup of a muffin tin before putting it in the oven. This will prevent any oil from leaking onto the bottom of your oven.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Check to see if the garlic is soft by poking it with a knife. After 40 minutes are up, unwrap the garlic and gently stick the pointed tip of your knife into the head. If it sinks in easily, the garlic is finished roasting. If it’s still slightly hard, rewrap the garlic and let it cook for 10 minutes before checking it again.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Larger heads of garlic will take longer to roast.</li>\n<li>Continue checking the garlic every 10 minutes after the 40-minute mark.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Remove the garlic from the oven and let it cool for 5 minutes. Set the garlic on a hot pad on the kitchen counter. When you’re ready to eat it, simply peel off a clove or use a knife to cut it away from the head.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>To store any leftover garlic, place it in an airtight container and keep it in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. You can also set the container in the freezer, where the garlic will last up to 3 months.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Making Stove-Roasted Garlic\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Stove-Roasted-Garlic\">Making Stove-Roasted Garlic</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Place  of olive oil and 25 to 30 garlic cloves in a skillet. Pour the oil into the bottom of a  skillet, then sprinkle in the cloves. Spread them evenly around the pan so they aren’t all clumped together in 1 area.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Don’t overcrowd the pan. The cloves shouldn’t overlap or form more than 1 layer on the bottom of the pan.</li>\n<li>You can use pre-peeled cloves or buy a head and peel the cloves yourself.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Heat the skillet over medium heat until the oil starts to sizzle. This will take about 2 to 3 minutes. Watch the skillet closely for the first sign of bubbling around the cloves.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you're using a stove with 9 settings, medium heat will be anywhere from 4 to 6.</li>\n<li>Don't leave the kitchen. If the cloves sit in the sizzling oil for too long, they'll fry instead of roast.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Reduce the heat to low and let the garlic cook for 20 to 30 minutes. As soon as you notice the oil sizzling, turn down the heat on the stove. Leave the cloves to roast and soften in the oil.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>To monitor the time, use the clock app on your phone or set a kitchen timer.</li>\n<li>You can stir the cloves occasionally while they cook to ensure they're coated in oil and cooking evenly.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Remove the cloves from the oil and let them cool before eating. Use a slotted spoon to take the cloves out of the skillet. If you're eating the garlic right away, wait 3 to 5 minutes for them to cool off.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you aren't using the garlic immediately, or if you have leftovers, you can store it in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks. You can also freeze it for up to 3 months.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You&#039;ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Oven-Roasted Garlic\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Oven-Roasted-Garlic_2\">Oven-Roasted Garlic</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Cutting board</li>\n<li>Knife</li>\n<li>Aluminum foil</li>\n<li>Airtight container (optional)</li>\n<li>Baking sheet (optional)</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Stove-Roasted Garlic\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stove-Roasted-Garlic_2\">Stove-Roasted Garlic</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Skillet</li>\n<li>Spoon for stirring</li>\n<li>Slotted spoon</li>\n<li>Airtight container (optional)</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Roast-Garlic&#38;action=edit&#38;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span
