href=\"https://www.thekitchn.com/how-to-roast-garlic-in-the-oven-5341\">https://www.thekitchn.com/how-to-roast-garlic-in-the-oven-5341</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/\">https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/\">https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/\">https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/\">https://toriavey.com/how-to/how-to-roast-garlic/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 25 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7a/Roast-Garlic-Step-13.jpg","linkMd5":"ba94225332a01ced385a7f195cd047e5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn46@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109671107_74f4d519da8c1214.webp","metaImg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/7a/Roast-Garlic-Step-13.jpg","author":""},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Make Solid Perfume","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Solid-Perfume","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Because it's easy to make, solid perfume opens the door to experimentation, creativity, and individuality. Whether you're looking to set yourself apart with a unique scent or you're not so fond of the alcoholic undertones in most liquid perfumes, these instructions will show you how to create an inexpensive alternative.\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Sweet and Subtle Perfume\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sweet-and-Subtle-Perfume\">Sweet and Subtle Perfume</span></h3>\n<ul><li>of beeswax</li>\n<li>of almond oil, jojoba oil, grapeseed oil, or olive oil</li>\n<li>10 drops of sandalwood essential oil</li>\n<li>5 to 10 drops of lavender essential oil</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Hearty Cologne\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hearty-Cologne\">Hearty Cologne</span></h3>\n<ul><li>of beeswax</li>\n<li>of almond oil, jojoba oil, grapeseed oil, or olive oil</li>\n<li>10 drops of frankincense essential oil</li>\n<li>5 to 10 drops of rosemary essential oil</li>\n<li>3 to 5 drops of bergamot essential oil</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Woody and Floral Perfume\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Woody-and-Floral-Perfume\">Woody and Floral Perfume</span></h3>\n<ul><li>of beeswax</li>\n<li>of almond oil, jojoba oil, grapeseed oil, or olive oil</li>\n<li>10 drops of jasmine essential oil</li>\n<li>5 to 10 drops of rose essential oil</li>\n<li>3 to 5 drops of cedarwood essential oil</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Creating a Scent\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-a-Scent\">Creating a Scent</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Mix your essential oils in a small dish to try out your scent. Before you dedicate an entire dish of perfume to one smell, you might want to test it to see if you like it first. Grab a small dish and use it to test out different scent combinations until you find one that you like. You can try different scents and ratios to experiment with your scent.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Solid Perfume Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Ramekins are a great size for this, but you can use any small container that you have on-hand.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pick 10 drops of a long-lasting essential oil as a base note. Base notes are slow to evaporate and will be a long-lasting scent in your perfume. You can pick cedarwood, frankincense, ginger, jasmine, or vanilla for this note. Pour in 25 drops of your choice as a base.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You need the most of your base note so it sticks around on your skin the longest.</li>\n<li>Pick sandalwood for a sweet and subtle perfume.</li>\n<li>Try frankincense for a woody scent.</li>\n<li>Pick jasmine for a floral note.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add 5 to 10 drops of a middle note that is slightly more subtle. Lavender, lemongrass, orange, and rosemary all make great middle notes. These scents won’t last quite as long and help to support the base note.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Try lavender oil to round out a sweet and subtle perfume.</li>\n<li>Pick rosemary for a more cologne-like scent.</li>\n<li>Try rose oil for a floral perfume.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Choose 3 to 5 drops of a top note that’s uplifting. Top notes are what you’ll smell first, but they’ll also go away super quickly. Choose from grapefruit, juniper, lime, pine, and tangerine as a short but sweet top note.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Try bergamot for a citrus scent.</li>\n<li>Mix in cedarwood essential oil for a woody note.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Combining Your Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Combining-Your-Ingredients\">Combining Your Ingredients</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Put a glass bowl in a saucepan half full of water over medium heat. Grab a large saucepan and fill it up with water from your tap so it’s about half full. Place a glass bowl in the center of the saucepan and turn the stove to medium to create a double boiler.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you have a double boiler, you can use that instead.</li>\n<li>Beeswax doesn’t melt down well in the microwave, and you probably won’t get an even, smooth mixture. The stovetop is your best bet.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pour your beeswax and carrier oil into the glass bowl. Carrier oil is a fragrance-free oil that will thin out the beeswax. Add  of beeswax and  of your carrier oil to the glass bowl.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can use almond oil, jojoba oil, grapeseed oil, or olive oil for your carrier oil.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Heat the carrier oil and beeswax mixture for 2 to 3 minutes. The carrier is already a liquid, but beeswax is solid. Heat the mixture for a few minutes until the beeswax melts into a pourable liquid.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Remove the bowl from the heat and stir the mixture. Use oven mitts and carefully take your glass bowl off the sauce pan. Use a wooden stick to combine the wax and the oil together until they look smooth and shiny.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Your wooden stick will get wax on it, so don’t use anything that you’d like to cook with later on.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Stir your chosen essential oils into the hot mixture. Gently pour your essential oil mixture into the wax and oil, then use your wooden stirrer to combine all of your ingredients. Try not to spend too long on this, or the wax could start to harden up.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>The essential oil will probably smell really intense at first, but that’s okay! It will spread out in the wax mixture.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pour the perfume mixture into 3 to 4 small containers with lids. Pick out a few  containers that can be sealed with a lid to store your perfume. Carefully pour a small amount into each container, being careful not to spill any of the wax.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Solid Perfume Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-10.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can use empty mint tins as a cute way to store your perfume.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Let the wax cool and harden for 1 to 2 hours. Once your mixture hardens, you now have perfume! You can give some of the containers away as a gift or keep them all for yourself to stock up on a great scent.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Solid Perfume Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-11.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Don’t use your perfume until it’s fully dry, or you could burn yourself.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Using and Storing the Perfume\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-and-Storing-the-Perfume\">Using and Storing the Perfume</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Rub a cotton swab or your finger over the perfume. You don’t need to press down very hard to pick up the scent of your perfume. Gently dab your finger or a cotton swab onto the waxy surface until you see a slight indent in the perfume.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>The more perfume you pick up, the stronger the scent will be.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Dab the perfume onto your wrists and behind your ears. Perfume smells the best and lasts the longest on your wrists, your neck, and right behind your ears, since you emit more heat from those areas. Gently rub it into your skin for a soothing, pleasant aroma.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Solid perfume isn’t quite as strong as liquid perfume, so you don’t have to worry about applying too much.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Store your sealed perfume in a cool, dry place for 6 to 12 months. Keep a lid on your perfume container whenever you aren’t using it. If you used grapeseed as a carrier, use your perfume within 6 months. If you used olive oil, jojoba oil, or almond oil, you can keep it around for 12 months.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Solid Perfume Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-14.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Grapeseed oil breaks down faster than other types of oil, which is why it doesn’t stay as fresh.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>When you make your own perfume, it’s customizable to what you like. Experiment with different scents to figure out what you’d like to smell like.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Always use oven mitts when taking the beeswax off the stove.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Small dish</li>\n<li>Saucepan</li>\n<li>Glass bowl</li>\n<li>Wooden stirrer</li>\n<li>Small containers with lids</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Solid-Perfume&#38;action=edit&#38;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"343918b0f305bc46d2158718b5946f61","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn75@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662218_78af08c862796bad.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn75@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662218_78af08c862796bad.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-10.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn73@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109670952_58821bb38ffb80dc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-11.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn66@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109670891_7cdbe1bb61eb4723.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-14.jpg/aid179552-v4-728px-Make-Solid-Perfume-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn77@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676017_71b1ff861e0de79e.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>There’s nothing worse than finding the perfect pair of open toed leather shoes and then realizing that they’re too tight. Returning shoes can be a hassle, and finding the right size for your feet can be difficult. Fortunately, there are a couple different ways that you can stretch out your shoes to make them a little more comfortable to wear.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Stretching Your Shoes with Ice\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stretching-Your-Shoes-with-Ice\">Stretching Your Shoes with Ice</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Fill 2 plastic bags with about  of water. Try to fill each bag up about halfway, then seal them tightly. Make sure there aren’t any holes where the water could spill out.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Pick bags that are small enough to fit inside of your shoes, like sandwich bags.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Push the bags of water into the toes of your shoes. Double check that the bags are sealed tightly, then shove them as far down into your shoes as you can. Make sure about  of the bag is sticking out of the toe portion of your shoe.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Using a bag of water will mostly widen the toe portion of your shoes, and not so much the heel area.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Put your shoes in the freezer for about 3 hours. As the water freezes, the ice will expand inside of your shoe, stretching out the leather. You can check on your shoes periodically to see how frozen the water is, but it usually takes 3 to 4 hours.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Take your shoes out and remove the bags of ice. Once the ice is frozen, you can take your shoes out and test how much they have stretched. Dump out the ice but save the bags so that you can reuse them if you need to.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Repeat the process as many times as you need to. Since ice only expands so much, you may have to put bags of ice in your shoes 2 to 3 times. If this method doesn’t work, you can take your shoes to a professional cobbler for a stretching service.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The amount of times you use this method depends on how tight the leather in your shoes is and how much you need them to stretch.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Heating Your Shoes with a Hair Dryer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Heating-Your-Shoes-with-a-Hair-Dryer\">Heating Your Shoes with a Hair Dryer</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Put on a pair of thick socks and your leather shoes. Thick socks will protect your feet from the heat of your hair dryer, which can get really hot. Pull your open toed leather shoes on over your socks as best you can.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>It may be difficult to get your shoes on over the socks, but it’s really important to protect your feet from the hair dryer so they don’t get burned.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Aim your hair dryer at the areas that are too tight for 10 minutes. Turn your hair dryer on high heat and point it at the areas of your shoes that are too snug, like the toes or heel. Pass quickly over your shoes so that they don’t get hot, and keep doing this for about 10 minutes.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Keep your shoes on while they cool down for about 10 minutes. As your shoes cool, they will form to the shape of your feet. Leave your shoes on for a little bit so they conform to the larger size.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you take your shoes off while they’re still warm, they could shrink in size.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Apply a leather conditioner to rehydrate your shoes. Heat can dry out leather, so it’s important to rehydrate your shoes once you’re done. Dab a small amount of leather conditioner onto a clean cloth and rub it in a circular direction all over the outside of your shoes.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 9 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can find leather conditioner online or at most leather shops.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Shoe Stretcher\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Shoe-Stretcher\">Using a Shoe Stretcher</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Spray shoe stretcher spray all over your shoe. Shoe stretcher spray will soften the leather of your shoe and make it more malleable. Spray a thin layer of it all over the outside of your shoe to get it ready for the stretching tool.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can find stretching spray at most shoe stores. You can also find it in a liquid version that you rub into your shoe with a clean cloth.</li>\n<li>Shoe stretcher spray is a leather conditioner that soaks the shoe to make it more pliable without damaging it.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Let the spray soak in for 1 to 2 minutes. Set your shoe down on a flat surface and give the spray some time to soak into the leather. You may still see a slight shine from the spray, but it shouldn’t pool up anywhere on your shoe.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you don’t let the spray soak in first, it might not work as well.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Insert the shoe stretcher into your shoe. Shoe stretchers look like wooden feet with a metal bar sticking out the back. High heel shoe stretchers conform to the shape of the heel so you don’t have to worry about warping your shoe. Slide the tool into your shoe and situate it so that you can see the “toe” of the stretcher sticking out of the toe of your shoe.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 12 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can find shoe stretchers at most shoe stores.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Turn the handle of the stretcher clockwise 6 to 8 times. The metal handle on the back of the stretcher pushes the inside of the stretcher open. Turn the handle 3 to 4 times until the stretcher is snug in the shoe, then turn it 3 to 4 more times to give it a stretch.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 13 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The shoe stretcher will widen your shoes from the toe to the heel. Unfortunately, it won’t make them any longer.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Leave your shoe stretcher in your shoe for 1 to 2 days. The leather of your shoes needs time to adhere to its new shape. Keep your shoe in a cool, dry place, like your closet, for at least 24 hours before taking it out.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Stretch Open Toe Leather Shoes Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you have 2 shoe stretchers, you can stretch both your shoes at the same time. Otherwise, just do one shoe at a time.</li>\n<li>The shoe stretcher spray will absorb into your shoes, so you don’t need to worry about wiping it off.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you can’t get your shoes to stretch, take them to a professional cobbler for a stretching service.</li></ul>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Stretching Your Shoes with Ice\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Stretching-Your-Shoes-with-Ice_2\">Stretching Your Shoes with Ice</span></h3>\n<ul><li>2 plastic bags</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Heating Your Shoes with a Hair Dryer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Heating-Your-Shoes-with-a-Hair-Dryer_2\">Heating Your Shoes with a Hair Dryer</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Thick socks</li>\n<li>Hair dryer</li>\n<li>Leather conditioner</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Shoe Stretcher\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Shoe-Stretcher_2\">Using a Shoe Stretcher</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Shoe stretcher spray</li>\n<li>Shoe stretcher</li></ul>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stretch-your-shoes-2015-2\">https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stretch-your-shoes-2015-2</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.vogue.co.uk/article/how-to-stretch-shoes-and-leather\">https://www.vogue.co.uk/article/how-to-stretch-shoes-and-leather</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=115\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=115</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=52\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=52</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=105\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=105</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=114\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QohsNMsplqI&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=114</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-14\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stretch-your-shoes-2015-2\">https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-stretch-your-shoes-2015-2</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"421da7e948484e8d8549111429d6392e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109662792_7859180835a49f44.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn39@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109662792_7859180835a49f44.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn74@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109671108_281d351c8b2ba3cc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn34@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109672203_4a102694003cfb9b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn50@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673527_9014ab746e514abe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/93/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn30@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673520_dbe8cb9f336d6f72.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/61/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn37@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109670971_1eae20c2d84d162f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn93@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109671053_b725cf94982a2b3b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn49@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672779_495746d392fcfe7d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn37@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676621_1fc38b204c3ada03.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109671127_f41cd996884d6482.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn94@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109670869_1ab2bd107939af49.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn86@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673812_a5f0c4900ed54df9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-13-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn2@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109670880_e22ab7463fdacf5b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid11906329-v4-728px-Stretch-Open-Toe-Leather-Shoes-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn41@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109676800_960f9858c61e7415.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Cut Fresh Rosemary","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Fresh rosemary is a great way to add some herby flavor and freshness to a wide variety of dishes. If you’re <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Rosemary\" title=\"Grow Rosemary\">growing your own rosemary</a>, you can cut fresh rosemary right off the plant to use or store. Once you've harvested or purchase fresh sprigs of rosemary, you can use either a chef’s knife or kitchen scissors to chop or mince the rosemary leaves into the desired consistency. Soon enough, you’ll be sprinkling fresh, fragrant rosemary into all kinds of recipes!\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Trimming Rosemary From a Plant\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Trimming-Rosemary-From-a-Plant\">Trimming Rosemary From a Plant</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Harvest rosemary in the spring or summer if you want it to grow back. Wait until the growing season, which is during spring and summer after the last winter frost, to harvest fresh rosemary. This way, it will grow back and replenish itself.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut Fresh Rosemary Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can trim sprigs of rosemary off your plants whenever you want to use some, but just know that if you harvest rosemary during the fall or winter it won’t grow back until the following spring.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Snip off rosemary stems at the base using sharp garden shears or scissors. Get as close to the place where the stem comes off the main stock of the rosemary plant. Ensure your garden shears or scissors are very sharp so you can easily cut through the woody stalks of the rosemary sprigs.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>This method applies to both rosemary plants in a garden and potted rosemary plants.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Cut up to 1/3 of the stems off a rosemary plant at one time. Try to take stems from various parts of the rosemary plant rather than all from the same spot and don’t cut off more than 1/3 of the plant’s growth at any given time. This will allow the plant to grow back healthy new stems and replenish itself.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut Fresh Rosemary Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-3.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Make sure you let the plant replace the growth you cut away before you harvest from it again.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Take smaller, younger stems from rosemary plants for the freshest taste. Trim off the smallest, newest stems when you harvest fresh rosemary if you want the most rosemary flavor from the leaves. The young leaves are also the most fragrant.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can either use fresh rosemary right away, store it in airtight containers for up to 2 weeks, or dry it and store it indefinitely.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Freeze or dry unused fresh rosemary to preserve it. Put fresh rosemary sprigs in a freezer bag and store them in the freezer for up to 6 months if you want to keep them fresh. Tie rosemary sprigs together in bundles and hang them up in an airy, dry place inside your home if you want dried rosemary.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut Fresh Rosemary Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-5.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can also dry rosemary out in the oven by spreading the sprigs out on a baking sheet and putting them in the oven at the lowest possible temperature for 2-4 hours. Alternatively, you can use a food dehydrator if you have one.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Chopping and Mincing Rosemary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Chopping-and-Mincing-Rosemary\">Chopping and Mincing Rosemary</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Rinse fresh rosemary under cool running water. Place sprigs of freshly-harvested or purchased rosemary into a strainer or colander. Hold the rosemary under the faucet of your kitchen sink and turn the cold water on. Move the strainer or colander around under the stream of water and move the sprigs around with one of your hands until you thoroughly rinse off all the rosemary.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut Fresh Rosemary Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-6.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Always wash your rosemary and strip the leaves off of the stems before you cut rosemary to clean off any dirt or pesticides and separate the leaves from the tough woody stems, which are not usable.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use paper towels or a salad spinner to dry the rosemary. Lay the sprigs of rosemary out on a doubled-up paper towel on a kitchen counter and pat them dry with another paper towel or two. Place the sprigs in a salad spinner and spin the handle to dry off the rosemary as an alternative to using paper towels.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>It’s easier to cut rosemary when it’s dry. If the leaves are wet, they can stick together, making it more difficult to cut them uniformly.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Run your fingers along a stem of rosemary to strip the leaves off. Hold a sprig of rosemary in one hand by the end of its stem. Place the index finger and thumb of your other hand just below where you are holding the stem, then run your fingers firmly down the length of the stem to strip the leaves off.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can do this over a cutting board, a measuring cup, a bowl, or another container of some kind.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place fresh rosemary leaves onto a cutting board. Set a cutting board on your kitchen counter or another flat work surface. Put leaves stripped from a fresh sprig of rosemary into the center of the cutting board.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cut Fresh Rosemary Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-9.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Try to cut only as much rosemary as you plan to use. Fresh rosemary will last longer if you keep it intact.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Arrange the leaves into a neat pile with all the tips going in the same direction. Bunch the leaves together as closely as you can using both hands to scrape them into a neat pile. Inspect the pile carefully and reposition any leaves that are facing in different directions.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>This will make it easier to cut the rosemary into equally-sized pieces.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use a chef’s knife to slice one way across the leaves to chop the rosemary. Start at one end of the pile of rosemary leaves and slice across them horizontally. Work your way down the entire length of the pile, slicing in the same direction, until you have a pile of uniformly-chopped rosemary.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you do end up chopping too much rosemary, you can store the leftover pieces in a sealable plastic bag or a small jar for up to about 2 weeks.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Slice the leaves again, going the other way across the pile, to mince the rosemary. Turn your cutting board or your knife 90 degrees so you can cut across the leaves in the other direction. Start at one end of the pile and chop your way along the pile until the rosemary is minced into small pieces.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can repeat this process multiple times, alternating which way you slice across the pile of leaves, if you want very finely-minced pieces of rosemary.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Snip the rosemary leaves up using sharp kitchen scissors as an alternative. Put the fresh rosemary leaves into a measuring cup or bowl. Use the tips of a pair of kitchen scissors to snip up the rosemary leaves using short, fast strokes and going back and forth across the pile of leaves. Keep snipping the rosemary until you get the consistency you want.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you don’t have kitchen scissors, you can use a pair of sharp household scissors. If you do so, make sure to wash them with soap and water first.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Trimming Rosemary From a Plant\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Trimming-Rosemary-From-a-Plant_2\">Trimming Rosemary From a Plant</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Sharp garden shears or scissors</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Chopping and Mincing Rosemary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Chopping-and-Mincing-Rosemary_2\">Chopping and Mincing Rosemary</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Fresh rosemary sprigs</li>\n<li>Colander or strainer</li>\n<li>Cutting board</li>\n<li>Chef’s knife</li>\n<li>Measuring cup or bowl (optional)</li>\n<li>Kitchen scissors (optional)</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cut-Fresh-Rosemary&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T_D6GTmKgT8&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=25\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T_D6GTmKgT8&#38;feature=youtu.be&#38;t=25</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-3\"><a class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.almanac.com/plant/rosemary\">https://www.almanac.com/plant/rosemary</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-5\"><a
