target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/\">https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/\">https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme\">https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme\">https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme\">https://www.realsimple.com/food-recipes/shopping-storing/herbs-spices/chop-rosemary-thyme</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://forknplate.com/2013/04/09/how-to-mince-rosemary/\">https://forknplate.com/2013/04/09/how-to-mince-rosemary/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://forknplate.com/2013/04/09/how-to-mince-rosemary/\">https://forknplate.com/2013/04/09/how-to-mince-rosemary/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/\">https://www.bhg.com/recipes/how-to/cooking-basics/cooking-fresh-herbs/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"b19b65308b470b5a83d7c481a15f35de","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn35@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662761_3eb7bf8b74418b06.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn35@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662761_3eb7bf8b74418b06.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-3.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn53@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674589_d2294bcb9cd6393c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-5.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn54@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672248_7ef4b867d73c8908.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-6.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109672272_02707ab1fc02cfe6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-9.jpg/aid11748122-v4-728px-Cut-Fresh-Rosemary-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn13@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109675873_87b5ef61fa5a6d61.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Hike the Pacific Crest Trail","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>The Pacific Crest Trail is a national park that runs parallel to the West Coast of North America. It goes north and south through California, Oregon, Washington, and ends in British Columbia, Canada. All together, it is roughly  of serene hiking and views, and it is the second largest collection of trails anywhere in the world.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> To hike the entire trail would take roughly 6 months, but most people spend less than a week on the trail. Keep in mind, you need to file for the proper permits before going out to hike the Pacific Crest Trail.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Planning Your Hike\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Planning-Your-Hike\">Planning Your Hike</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Choose at least one other person to go hiking with you. Portions of the trail are pretty remote, and you could end up in serious danger if you injure an ankle or run into trouble and there’s no one around to help you out. Reach out to a friend or contact a fellow hiking enthusiast to go with you. If you don’t know any viable candidates, go online to a community hiking site or social media group and look for a travel buddy there.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>In parts of the trail, it’s actually illegal to hike on your own. This is entirely for safety reasons—there are just too many things that can go wrong if you hike the Pacific Crest Trail alone.</li>\n<li>The Pacific Crest Trail is not an everyday hike. In many portions of the trail, the going can get pretty rough. Consider hiking another trail first if this is your first time going hiking.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pick the direction you want to hike the trail. The southern portion of the trail is mostly deserts and rocky terrain. Then it runs through Central and Northern California, which includes the famous Sierra Nevada and features dozens of mountains. Next, Oregon is mostly flat and filled with forests, before Washington and British Columbia become mountainous again. Choose the direction you want to go based on the terrain you’re looking to experience.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Take the weather into account based on the direction you’re going. You cannot start a 2-week northbound trip in late August if you’re starting off in Washington since you’ll risk running into snow. Similarly, it’s going to be dangerous to try hiking in Southern California in the summer. Check the weather for the area you plan on hiking and try to line your hike up so that you aren’t running into terrible temperatures and extreme precipitation.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Check the forecasts in 1-month increments in the time leading up to your hike. This will keep you from getting pumped for a hike that probably needs to be rescheduled.</li>\n<li>You can pull up a detailed set of forecasts for each portion of the trail on the PCTA’s website.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Schedule your hike between April and May if you’re northbound. Over 90% of hikers head out in the early spring and go northbound. Whether you start out near the Mexican border, Central California, or somewhere in Oregon or Washington, the best time to head out is between April and May after the snow melts and the weather warms a little.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you’re hiking for a long period of time, this will make sure you’re north by the time the weather gets really hot. If you’re hiking a short period of time, you’ll beat the brutal heat in the southern half of the trail by a month or so.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Go hiking in late June or July if you’re going south. If you’re starting in British Columbia, Washington, or Oregon, wait until the late summer to hike south. This way, you won’t be south until the hot weather has dissipated. If you’re only hiking a short period of time, hiking the northern half in the summer will keep you comfortable.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Even in the height of summer, the weather in British Columbia, Washington, and Oregon doesn’t get that hot. For example, Seattle averages roughly  during July. This is not hot enough to wear yourself out on the trail but warm enough to comfortably fall asleep at night.</li>\n<li>Stay out of the southern third of the trail in the summer months. It will get extremely hot in the desert.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Avoid hiking the north end in the winter and the south end in the summer. Regardless of when you’re going and where you’re hiking, the ultimate goal is to avoid the northern half in the winter and the southern half in the summer. Not only is the trail uncomfortable during these times, it’s extremely dangerous.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-6.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The average low in Washington during January is . When it’s that cold, you can’t sleep, and you’re at risk of frost bite, hypothermia, and freezing to death.</li>\n<li>The average high in Southern California during August is around , but it regularly exceeds , especially in the desert. You’d be at risk of dehydration, heat stroke, and sunburn if you go hiking in this kind of weather.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Selecting Your Route\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Selecting-Your-Route\">Selecting Your Route</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Buy or find a detailed map of the Pacific Crest Trail. You can use an online map while you’re planning, but you’ll need a physical copy when you’re out on the trail. Make sure that you map includes the name of every national park and wilderness area since you’ll need these names for permit planning. Any official trail map should work just fine for this.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-7.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Choose a route to hike based on proximity and desired terrain. One way to plan your route is to simply start in the area closet to where you live. If you’re traveling to the region specifically to hike the Pacific Crest Trail, you can start wherever you’d like based on the type of terrain you’re looking to hike. Much of the trail is mountainous, but Oregon is mostly forested and the southern end of the trail is mostly desert. Select a specific route based on where you enjoy hiking.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup> off of the Pacific Crest Trail in Central California.}}<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-8.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Some hikers pick an end to start at and hike the entire trail in portions over the course of their lifetime.</li>\n<li>There’s no wrong place to start. The entire trail is beautiful and you really shouldn’t focus too much on finding the “best” spot. Just choose a type of terrain you want to see!</li></ul></li>\n<li>Determine how much time it’ll take based on how far you want to go. With lightweight gear, a quick pace, and a serious lack of breaks, you’ll make it  a day. Under normal conditions though, you’re probably only going to get  a day. Sit down and figure out how much time it’ll take based on your initial route.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-9.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This is especially important if you’re taking time off of work or plan on hiking during a break from school.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Identify the resupply points and adjust your route accordingly. There are various towns and shops along the trail. Identify all of the resupply points in the area where you’re planning to hike. Then, shift your starting point up or down so that you reach the first resupply point when you think you’ll be down to roughly ½ of your food and water supply. This way, you’ll ensure that you never run dangerously low on food and water.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-10.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Many people mail themselves resupply packages along the route so they don’t need to spend 1-2 hours shopping at each supply point.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n<li>You can find a complete list of resupply points online.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n<li>The resupply points are kind of designed to be reasonably close to one another if you’re hiking in California. There are a few stretches in the norther half where you won’t find one for . Always check your map before leaving a supply point to make sure you have enough food and water.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Your Permits\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Your-Permits\">Getting Your Permits</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Identify every park and wilderness area you’re hiking through. About half of the Pacific Crest Trail requires a permit, especially if you’re spending the night on it. You need permits specifically to enter or camp in designated/protected wilderness areas (usually shown in green on a map), national parks, and you need separate permits for California State Parks. Compile a list of every permit-restricted area you plan on passing through.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>. If you’re going more than , apply for a long-term permit through the PCTA (Pacific Crest Trail Agency). You may need additional permits, but they’ll walk you through it. Visit <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.pcta.org/discover-the-trail/permits/pct-long-distance-permit/\">https://www.pcta.org/discover-the-trail/permits/pct-long-distance-permit/</a> to apply.}}<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-11.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Start applying for permits at least 3 months before your hike. You’ll need to register them 3 weeks in advance, and they can take time to process.</li>\n<li>If you’re hiking only through Oregon or Washington, you can get permits at the kiosks where you enter the parks. You do not need to worry about permits if you’re hiking through these states alone.</li>\n<li>You need your passport if you’re doing the entire trail. You’ll need it to get across the Canadian-US border.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Go to each individual park agency’s website to file for your permits. This is where things get a little complicated. You need a permit from every park and wilderness agency to hike or camp through it. Pull up the website for every agency you’re traveling through and apply for a permit on their website. Fill in all of the details and submit your personal information to apply.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-12.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Almost all of these permits are free. The parks require them so they can monitor how many people are on the trail, limit the environmental impact, and ensure that there’s record of where you are in the event you get lost or go missing.</li>\n<li>In the United States, you’ll apply for the vast majority of permits on the USA’s government recreation page.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Get a California fire permit to cook in the state of California. If you’re hiking in any portion of California, you also need a California fire permit if you plan on cooking any hot meals. If you aren’t bringing a burner or personal stove, don’t worry about it. Otherwise, complete an online course and take a quiz to print one off online.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-13.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can take this class and apply for the permit online.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup></li>\n<li>The California fire permit does not let you start campfires; it only lets you cook hot food on a controlled flame. If you plan on setting up any campfires, you need to apply for a campfire permit online as well.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Apply for a Canada PCT permit if you’re crossing the border at any point. If you plan on hiking from the United States to Canada, You need a Canada PCT permit to enter Canada. The PCTA has a special agreement with Canada, but the permit lets the authorities in Canada know that you’re coming so they can do a preliminary background check.<sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-14.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Fill out an application online at the PCTA’s website.<sup id=\"_ref-22\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 22\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-22\">[22]</a></sup> Then, email your application to pacificcresttrail@cbsa-asfc.gc.ca.</li>\n<li>If you’re American or Canadian, you don’t need a special permit to go from Canada to the United States. You only need your passport. You do need a visa if you’re a foreign national, though.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Enjoying Your Hike Safely\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Enjoying-Your-Hike-Safely\">Enjoying Your Hike Safely</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Pick up your <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Buy-Hiking-Gear\" title=\"Buy Hiking Gear\">hiking gear</a> 2-3 weeks before your trip. Get your hiking shoes and boots, your paper map, a compass and GPS unit, and all of your weather-appropriate clothing. You’ll also need a flashlight, emergency fire kit, emergency signal, and first aid kit. Get a tent, sleeping bag, and sunscreen as well. Pick up everything you need 2-3 weeks before you plan on heading out to give yourself time to pack and prepare your backpack.<sup id=\"_ref-23\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 23\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-23\">[23]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-15.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Purchase enough food and water to make it to the first supply point. Get some high-calorie dehydrated food to make sure you have plenty of energy before you reach your first supply point. Get at least  of water for every hour of hiking you’ll be doing. Include  of food per day. Pack plenty of snacks and cooking equipment to prepare your food.<sup id=\"_ref-24\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 24\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-24\">[24]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-16.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>In addition to dehydrated food, include some cereal, sauce packets, trail mix, jerky, or canned fish just to mix things up.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Stick to your schedule to avoid violating permits or losing time. Don’t mess around with your schedule. If you need to hike at least  a day to reach a supply point in 2 days, hanging out in a spot for an entire day could be extremely dangerous. In addition, you may end up violating your permit dates and risk getting fined and kicked off of the trail.<sup id=\"_ref-25\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 25\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-25\">[25]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-17.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Watch your footing while you’re out and stay on the trail. Pay attention to where you’re walking, especially if you’re in a mountainous area. If you lose your footing and get hurt, you could end up in a sticky situation. Similarly, if you aren’t paying attention, you may accidentally wander off of the trail and get lost. Just keep an eye on your compass and check to make sure you’re heading the right way while you hike.<sup id=\"_ref-26\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 26\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-26\">[26]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-18.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Abandon the hike if you’re injured or the weather gets too rough. If you get injured, it’s key that you get help as soon as possible. If something goes wrong on the hike, you can’t just power through without risking your life. Similarly, if a storm pins you in place for more than a few hours, you probably need to abandon the hike. You may run into supply problems if you don’t call it and you’re close to running out of food or water.<sup id=\"_ref-27\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 27\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-27\">[27]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-19.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you get injured, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Call-911\" title=\"Call 911\">call 911</a>. They’ll pass you through to a rescue team that will retrieve you from the trail.</li>\n<li>If it’s a non-emergency but you’re in a sticky situation, call the sheriff’s office for the country you’re in. They’ll tell you what the best course of action is and will come out to assist if you need anything.</li>\n<li>If it snows, you basically have to call your hike. If you wake up with  of snow on the trail, you could be in serious danger.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Take plenty of photos and enjoy your hike. While you’re out on the trails, take plenty of photos to share with friends back home, crack jokes with your travel companion, and enjoy some of the freshest air you’ll ever find. Take the views in and enjoy the adventure.<sup id=\"_ref-28\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 28\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-28\">[28]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-20.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Hike the Pacific Crest Trail Step 20.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-20.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-20.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Only 2,607 people have ever hiked the entire trail. Out of those hikers, only 47 people have completed the trail more than once. Roughly 800 people attempt to hike the entire trail every year. This makes it one of the most difficult thru hikes in the world!<sup id=\"_ref-29\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 29\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-29\">[29]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>You must travel with a hiking group and hike at least  a day if you’re going to do the entire trail. The vast majority of full trail hikes go northbound from the Mexican border. If at any point it snows on your trip, you must abandon it. Keep in mind, the vast majority of attempts to do the entire trail are not successful.<sup id=\"_ref-30\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 30\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-30\">[30]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Unless you’re an absolute pro, do not go hiking in the snow. It’s too hard to make progress and you’re seriously risking your health if you get stuck in the snow.<sup id=\"_ref-31\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 31\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-31\">[31]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2>\n<ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Thru%E2%80%90Hike-the-Appalachian-Trail\" title=\"Thru‐Hike the Appalachian Trail\">Thru‐Hike the Appalachian Trail</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Prepare-for-Hiking-the-Appalachian-Trail\" title=\"Prepare for Hiking the Appalachian Trail\">Prepare for Hiking the Appalachian Trail</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hike-Half-Dome\" title=\"Hike Half Dome\">Hike Half Dome</a></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/opinion/nicholas-kristof-you-think-your-winter-was-rough.html\">https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/05/opinion/nicholas-kristof-you-think-your-winter-was-rough.html</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"5d35451cf49b84cf6cd40a2ce3145ace","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn71@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662200_948925b540179608.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn71@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662200_948925b540179608.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn81@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109677059_f0d60ae3a7e95b0e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn25@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674869_73b7f90d076e654f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn13@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109674827_6f8f809565b12c78.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn74@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673680_3e9190c66938b76b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-6.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn50@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109671049_d8cca2699767ed32.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-7.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn29@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109674942_0ced65e990700f42.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-8.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn81@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674615_aa52f58e209fa6c9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-9.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn82@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673751_61fedf7ffc885f7b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-10.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn9@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109673867_ee85e155662a41e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-11.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675174_f4ee9aa8d2f6de69.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-12.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn25@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672451_1be5e92b9077eab7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-13.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn17@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109670876_74c73b06eec557f3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-14.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn45@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109676017_99cc2e1b4dc490aa.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-15.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674402_75daa1ef61e8f07f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-16.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn53@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674984_7324fccd129535ef.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/52/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-17.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn37@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675985_f759bb9f1b94472e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-18.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn49@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109676730_f803c5aaa76d52aa.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-19.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn37@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109674902_d93edbbb87aeb2d3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9f/Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-20.jpg/aid1478866-v4-728px-Hike-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-Step-20.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn49@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109674584_541d04910aa93d20.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Tie a Dimple","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-a-Dimple","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>A tie dimple refers to the small indent in the center of a tie near the top of the knot. It adds another dimension to your outfit by giving your tie a little personality and class. A dimple can be applied to any type of necktie knot, although they tend to naturally occur with Eldridge, Capsule, and Nicky knots. To add your dimple, tie your tie the way you normally would, and stop right before you get to the part where you tighten the knot. Then, you can choose to add your dimple from the top or bottom of the knot.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Tying Your Tie\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tying-Your-Tie\">Tying Your Tie</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Choose your necktie and set the length before <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Tie-a-Tie\" title=\"Tie a Tie\">making the knot</a>. Select the necktie you think that goes best with your outfit. Line the blade and tail up over your shoulders to set the length. Then, begin to assemble the knot. A dimple is easily added to any kind of knot, so it doesn’t matter which particular knot you choose.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The blade refers to the larger piece of fabric that hangs in front. The tail is the skinnier piece of the tie that sits behind the blade.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Stop tying the tie at the point where you’re about to secure the knot. When you get to the part where you pull the blade down all the way through the knot to tighten the tie, stop. Slide the blade 3/4 of the way through the knot and gently let the tie hang. Leave at least  of space between the portion of the blade looped over the knot and the top of the knot itself.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-2.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Maintain enough slack in the blade and knot to reach in between the space where the front portion of the knot covers the blade.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Line your tie up and check the length before adding the dimple. Make sure that the knot is assembled perfectly and that the blade is at the perfect length before proceeding. The bottom of the blade should rest over your belt buckle, so if there is  of space remaining between the top of the blade and the knot, your blade should be hanging roughly  above the belt buckle.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-3.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You cannot add a dimple after tightening your necktie, and the dimple won’t look nearly as good if you loosen the knot after adding it to adjust the length of your tie.</li>\n<li>If you need to reassemble the knot or adjust the length, repeat these steps to create a new knot.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Folding the Dimple from Above\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Folding-the-Dimple-from-Above\">Folding the Dimple from Above</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Slide your thumbs under the loop on top of the knot. Insert your thumbs underneath the portion of the blade that is loosely sticking out the top of the knot. Orient your palms to face up so that you’re holding the loop with the pads of your thumbs. Keep your hands as symmetrical as possible for an even dimple.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-4.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Folding the dimple from above is a little easier than adding it from below, but you have less control over the size of the dimple.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pinch the fabric inwards using both index fingers. Slide your index fingers over your thumbs and pinch them inwards to add a seam to the loop. Transfer your grip on the loop to your nondominant hand and hold the loop in place.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-5.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You don’t need to squeeze hard to hold the dimple in place.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Slide the blade down through the knot. Grab the blade just underneath the knot with your dominant hand. Maintain the dimple with your nondominant hand. Slowly pull the blade down to tighten your knot.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-6.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Secure the dimple by sliding it through the back of the knot. While you’re pulling the blade down to tighten it, maintain the dimple with your nondominant hand. Slide the dimple through the front of the knot. The dimple will slide behind the front of the knot and emerge underneath it. Pull the blade all the way through to tighten your tie and secure the dimple.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-7.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The dimple should sit in the middle of your tie. If it isn’t, you may be able to adjust the tie by pulling the indentation in the dimple to the left or the right.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Adding the Dimple from Below\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Adding-the-Dimple-from-Below\">Adding the Dimple from Below</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Pinch the center of the blade just below the knot with your index finger. Grab the edges of your blade just beneath the loose knot. Use your index finger to apply pressure to the center of the fabric and add your dimple. Hold the fabric in place with your thumb and middle finger while maintaining the dimple with the index finger on the same hand.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-8.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Some people use their nondominant hand to do this while other people prefer their dominant hand. Do whatever feels most comfortable to you.</li>\n<li>Adding the dimple from below requires a little more dexterity, but you have more control over the location and the size of the dimple.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Grip the sides of the knot gently with your other hand. Use your free hand to grab the edges of the knot by the bottom edge of the fabric. Do not squeeze or pull on the knot—the goal here is to simply stabilize it while you tighten your tie.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-9.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Most people naturally squeeze the knot a little when they normally their tie. Resist the urge to do this, since the dimple will be harder to hold in place if you don’t leave yourself some room inside of the knot.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pull the blade down . Begin pulling the blade down to tighten your tie using whatever hand you’re holding the dimple with. After pulling the tie down , slide your index finger up towards the knot to move the dimple upwards.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-10.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Tighten your tie slowly while sliding the dimple up the blade. Use your other hand to brace the knot and keep the shape of your tie. Continue pulling the blade down and sliding the dimple up until your tie is tight.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Tie-a-Dimple-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Tie a Dimple Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-11.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If the angle of the dimple looks a little off, gently tug the fabric under your knot to adjust the shape of your dimple.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Whether you add your dimple above or below the knot is really a matter of personal preference. Try it both ways to figure out what feels right to you.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Tie-a-Dimple&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/Nfpbu1t34RA?t=48\">https://youtu.be/Nfpbu1t34RA?t=48</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/\">https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/\">https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/\">https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/advice/a18471/tie-dimple-how-to-051313/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 25 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"5d7a285b8864d8b0c80002025dc7d040","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662735_595a8234ed297967.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn31@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662735_595a8234ed297967.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-2.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn42@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109672170_840dc22d719f7e7a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-3.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn33@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109674844_d0156c05de443dff.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-4.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn98@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109670973_31c4f60219b53a98.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-5.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn61@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675994_65c4eaf53dfdf25c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-6.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn45@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109676844_da4f6d88e9134ca5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-7.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn97@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109671103_3a7ab12adcf875b0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-8.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn30@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109672191_d7984e13a2c86dac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-9.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn90@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109673714_ab9f00cfe0aab693.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-10.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn77@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109670971_cef83497fbad5847.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Tie-a-Dimple-Step-11.jpg/aid11755230-v4-728px-Tie-a-Dimple-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn41@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109675885_1111cf98db151ae4.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Water Air Plants","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Water-Air-Plants","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Care-for-Air-Plants\" title=\"Care for Air Plants\">Air plants</a>, also known as Tillandsia, are popular, low-maintenance houseplants that don’t grow in soil. Instead, they pull the bulk of their needed nutrients from the air! To keep your air plant healthy and happy, it needs water about once a week. Bottled or filtered tap water works best—avoid watering your air plants with distilled water since the distillation process removes important nutrients.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Soaking Loose Air Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soaking-Loose-Air-Plants\">Soaking Loose Air Plants</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Fill a clean tub, bucket, or sink with bottled or filtered tap water. Choose a container or receptacle that can easily accommodate all of your air plants. Add room-temperature bottled or filtered tap water to the container. Make sure you use enough water to fully submerge each clump.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Always clean out the container before using it to water your air plants.</li>\n<li>Avoid using distilled water for this since the distillation process removes crucial nutrients.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Submerge your air plants in the water. Air plants don’t grow in pots or soil, so you can easily gather the small, loose clumps with your hands. Place each clump in the water bath and push it under the surface. You can soak multiple air plants simultaneously.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Water-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If your air plant is mounted to a surface, like a heavy shell or piece of driftwood, you'll probably need to mist it instead of submerging it.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Soak the plants for 20-30 minutes and shake off the excess water. The air plants may float up to the surface as they soak, which is fine—just make sure the majority of each clump stays submerged for the full 20-30 minutes. Then, grab each clump, remove it from the bath, and shake it off to get rid of excess water.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Water-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Excess water tends to collect between the center leaves if you don’t give them a gentle shake first, which can eventually lead to rot and other issues.</li>\n<li>If your air plants are particularly dry, leave them in the water for up to 1 hour.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Place each clump upside down on a paper towel to air-dry completely. Air-drying typically takes about 30 minutes, but large or intricate clumps can take longer. You can touch the center leaves with your fingertips to check for moisture. Return the plants to their original locations once they’re totally dry.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Water-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Always place clumps upside down to air-dry so excess moisture can drain away.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Repeat this process weekly to keep air plants healthy. If the leaves look pale-green and feel soft, water the plant more often. Curled or rolled leaves also indicate dehydration.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Water-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>During the winter months, you can reduce watering to every 2 weeks.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Misting Mounted Air Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Misting-Mounted-Air-Plants\">Misting Mounted Air Plants</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Fill a plastic spray bottle with bottled or filtered tap water. Use room-temperature water for the best results. Be sure to avoid using distilled water, which doesn’t contain the necessary nutrients your air plants need to thrive.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Water-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Spray each clump generously until the water is dripping off the leaves. Misting delivers enough water to your air plant as long as you’re generous and thorough. Saturate the plant until water is running off the leaves.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Water-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Mounted air plants often need to be misted because the object they're attached to can’t be submerged in water. If the object is porous, bulky, or heavy, it's better to mist the plants.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Mist your air plants at least once a week to keep them hydrated. Since they’re tropical or subtropical in nature, air plants will not last long without steady moisture.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> Thoroughly mist them at least once a week.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Water-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Water your plants more often if you notice signs of dehydration. Air plants can dry out more easily if you’re unable to submerge them in water. To prevent dehydration, watch for leaves that feel soft or look pale green. Leaves may also curl or roll up when they are dehydrated.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Water-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Extremely dehydrated leaves may turn brown and brittle at the tips.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n<li>A hydrated air plant will look lush with darker green leaves.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place mounted air plants in a location that gets good air circulation. Unevaporated moisture can cause air plants to rot. Keeping mounted air plants in an area that gets plenty of air circulation so the leaves can dry completely after each misting session.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Water-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Water Air Plants Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Water-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>For example, a spacious, uncluttered room that gets plenty of light is a great place for your air plants.</li>\n<li>Make sure the surface your air plant is mounted on does not hold or absorb water. For example, cork would not be a good surface because it soaks up water like a sponge.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you live in a frost-free environment, you can keep your air plant outside. Otherwise, keep it <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Care-for-Air-Plants-Indoors\" title=\"Care for Air Plants Indoors\">indoors</a> so that it stays warm, and plan to water it more often than you would water an air plant kept outside in hot, humid climates.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Soaking Loose Air Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Soaking-Loose-Air-Plants_2\">Soaking Loose Air Plants</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Tub, bucket, or sink</li>\n<li>Bottled or filtered tap water</li>\n<li>Paper towels</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Misting Mounted Air Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Misting-Mounted-Air-Plants_2\">Misting Mounted Air Plants</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Plastic spray bottle</li>\n<li>Bottled or filtered tap water</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Water-Air-Plants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\"
