href=\"https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/houseplants/air-plants.html\">https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/houseplants/air-plants.html</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/air-plants/\">https://hgic.clemson.edu/factsheet/air-plants/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-14\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/houseplants/air-plants.html\">https://gardeningsolutions.ifas.ufl.edu/plants/houseplants/air-plants.html</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 25 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"965ac4346ab7b1cc11a757a3ea21ec7b","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn79@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662370_b9605e741a819f63.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/29/Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn79@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662370_b9605e741a819f63.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Water-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn62@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109672157_5acbfaf984dd92a2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d1/Water-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn22@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109671974_cbece7aa365edfb3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Water-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn54@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109671012_6e538ac9a5113352.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/22/Water-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn9@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109671567_e7192dc212868f87.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Water-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn94@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672271_47b9da2ff1553d3b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Water-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn5@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109672361_580c05180ca36c4e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Water-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn1@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109673867_5b3fc77288a89381.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Water-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn46@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109673520_16611eb388612e8d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Water-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg/aid11781447-v4-728px-Water-Air-Plants-Step-10.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn29@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109675859_936b2318cc6ad05b.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Knit Baby Pants","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Knit-Baby-Pants","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Homemade baby clothes make precious heirlooms and because they're so small, you can knit them quickly! Knit 2 flat pieces of fabric in a stockinette stitch pattern and then seam them together at the sides to form the pants. Since you'll make the waist with a double rib stitch, which is slightly elastic, there's no need to mess with buttons or drawstrings. This makes this project great for new to intermediate knitters.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Casting On\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Casting-On\">Casting On</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Select a soft worsted weight yarn for the baby pants. Choose a 125-gram (4.5 oz or 285 yd/260 m) skein of worsted weight (#4) yarn in any color. You might see worsted weight labeled as afghan, aran, or medium-weight yarn. Although you can use yarn made from any material, choose yarn that's soft enough for the baby and that will wash well.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Keep the label from the skein of yarn so you can remember the washing instructions once you finish making the pants.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Make a slip knot with worsted weight yarn. To form a slip knot, pull the yarn and twist the end into a loop so the tail end is on top. Use 1 hand to hold the tail and slide your other index finger and thumb through the loop. Pinch the working yarn and bring it through the loop.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Slide the slip knot onto size US 7 (4.5 mm) knitting needles. Slip the loop of yarn onto a straight needle. Then, pull the yarn tail so the loop tightens around the needle. Stop pulling just when the knot is secure so you can easily insert your working needle into the stitch.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you do accidentally pull too tightly and you can't insert the needle into the stitch, gently tug on the loop while you hold the actual knot. This loosens the stitch so you can put the needle through it.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Cast on 36 stitches. Although there are several ways to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cast-On\" title=\"Cast On\">cast on</a>, one of the easiest ways for beginners is to knit a stitch. Instead of placing the stitch you just made on your right needle, insert the tip of your left needle into the loop and slide it back onto the left needle so you have 2 stitches on it. Keep knitting stitches and placing them back on the left needle until you have a total of 36 stitches on it.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You'll also need an extra set of size US 7 (4.5 mm) knitting needles so you can work each pant leg.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Ribbed Waist\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Ribbed-Waist\">Making a Ribbed Waist</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Work 13 rows of a basic 2 x 2 rib pattern to create the waist. For the rib, purl (p) 2 stitches and knit (k) 2 stitches across the whole row. When you reach the end of the first row, turn the work and p2, k2 across the next row. Make a total of 13 rows in the rib stitch.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Make 6 rows of the stockinette stitch pattern. For the first row of stockinette stitch, knit every stitch. To make the next row, purl every stitch. Work the following 4 rows by knitting the odd rows and purling the even rows.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You'll knit rows 1, 3, 5 and purl rows 2 and 4.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Work an increasing row for row 7. Once you've made 6 stockinette stitch rows, knit 1 stitch and make 1 left stitch (m1L). Then, k3, m1L across the row until there are just 2 stitches left. Knit the last 2 stitches to finish the increasing row.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You'll have 48 stitches on your needles once you finish this row.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Knit 22 more rows in the stockinette stitch pattern. Purl the row after your increasing row to make row 8 of the stockinette stitch pattern. Continue to alternate purling and knitting rows for another 21 rows.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-8.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Remember to knit the odd rows and purl the even rows.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Knitting the Legs\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Knitting-the-Legs\">Knitting the Legs</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Purl 24 stitches and pass the remaining 24 stitches to a spare needle. To work the row where the legs split off, purl 24 stitches. Then, slide each of the remaining 24 stitches onto a spare US size 7 (4.5 mm) knitting needle. You'll keep working the stitches that you just purled in order to make the right leg. Don't work the stitches on the spare needle just yet.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-9.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can use a spare standard needle or circular needle, depending on what you prefer.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place a stitch marker on the first stitch of the left leg and turn your work. Attach a stitch marker to the first stitch that you placed on the spare needle. This will help you remember that this is the beginning of the left leg. Turn your work over so you can knit the stitches on your working needles.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>If you don't have a stitch marker, attach a safety pin or small hair accessory to the stitch.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Work the stockinette stitch for 44 rows. Knit across every stitch in the row after you've split them. Then, continue to work the stockinette pattern down the entire right leg. Remember to knit the odd rows and purl the even rows.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You'll be working 24 stitches across each row instead of the 48 that you did for previous rows.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Make 6 rows in the seed stitch pattern. To give the pant's a little texture near the bottom of the leg, do 6 rows of seed stitch. K1, p1 across the entire first row of the seed stitch pattern. Then, p1, k1 across the second row of seed stitch. Work 4 more rows by alternating the stitches like this:<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Odd rows: *k1, p1*</li>\n<li>Even rows:  *p1, k1*</li></ul></li>\n<li>Bind off the right leg stitches. Now that you've made the right leg, bind off each stitch on your working knitting needles. You can bind them off knitwise or purlwise, but you don't have to bind the stitches off using the seed stitch pattern. Then, tie off the last stitch and leave a yarn tail that's about  long.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Work the left leg using the stockinette and seed stitch patterns. Go back to the stitch marker and purl each of the stitches in the row. Repeat the pattern that you used for the right leg. Stockinette stitch 44 rows and then make 6 rows in the seed stitch pattern. Once you finish with that, bind off the stitches of the left leg and tie a knot to secure the last stitch.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-14.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you placed the left leg stitches on a circular needle, slide them back onto your standard knitting needles before you begin working them.</li>\n<li>Leave a tail that's about  long so you can use it to join the leg pieces.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Create an identical fabric piece to the one you just made. Once you've completed 1 whole fabric piece that has 2 legs, repeat the steps to make an identical piece. You'll sew the sides together to form the pants since you didn't sew them in the round.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-15.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Use the same yarn and needles when working the second piece so it works out to be the same size.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Assembling the Pants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Assembling-the-Pants\">Assembling the Pants</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Lay the pants pieces side by side and thread a tapestry needle. Arrange both pieces of fabric so the right sides face up and 2 of the legs touch. Then, thread a tapestry needle with 1 of the long yarn tails that's at the bottom of the pant leg.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-16.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you prefer, use a darning needle instead of a tapestry needle.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use the mattress stitch to sew together the sides of the pants. To <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Mattress-Stitch\" title=\"Mattress Stitch\">mattress stitch</a>, insert the needle into the opposite stitch on the fabric. Pull to connect the pieces. Then, insert the needle between the horizontal bar of the stitches and work from side to side. Pull again when you reach the end of the pieces to tighten the stitches. Weave in the tail once you reach the top of the pants.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>The mattress stitch is a great stitch for seaming the stockinette stitch pattern since it creates an almost invisible seam.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Fold the pants and mattress stitch the other side of the legs. Fold the pants so the seamed side is on the right and the top piece of fabric is right-side up. Thread your needle again and sew together the other side of the pants. Work from the bottom of the pant legs up to the waist. Then, weave in the yarn tail.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Sew together the inner legs to finish the pants. Now that the pants are joined on the outer sides, use the mattress stitch to sew the inner legs together. This forms the crotch of the pants as well. Weave in the ends to finish the pants.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Knit Baby Pants Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-19.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If you'd like to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Knit-a-Gauge-Swatch\" title=\"Knit a Gauge Swatch\">check your gauge</a> before starting the pants, knit 28 rows of 19 stitches to get a  swatch.</li>\n<li>If you see part of a pattern surrounded by an asterisk (*), you should repeat the pattern inside. For example, if you see *k1, p1* k2 you'd knit 1, purl 1 until you reach the last 2 stitches, which you'd knit.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You&#039;ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>2 sets of US size 7 (4.5 mm) knitting needles</li>\n<li>1 skein (125 g/4.5 oz or 285 yd/260 m) of worsted weight (#4) yarn</li>\n<li>Tapestry needle</li>\n<li>Stitch marker</li>\n<li>Measuring tape</li>\n<li>Scissors</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Knit-Baby-Pants&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=326\">https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=326</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=361\">https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=361</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-15\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=623\">https://youtu.be/b2sQ777rFXM?t=623</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a href=\"#_ref-17\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/6tMJPqFBKOE?t=638\">https://youtu.be/6tMJPqFBKOE?t=638</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-18\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/6tMJPqFBKOE?t=307\">https://youtu.be/6tMJPqFBKOE?t=307</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6tMJPqFBKOE\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6tMJPqFBKOE</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://knitfarious.com/how-to-read-knitting-stitch-patterns-knitters-guide/\">https://knitfarious.com/how-to-read-knitting-stitch-patterns-knitters-guide/</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 27 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"9cfff50a5383e69553cb83d49eb0ac29","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn99@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662490_ad1c68986106690e.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn99@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109662490_ad1c68986106690e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-8.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn9@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109675722_6362e0e3bf2cbb8f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-9.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn70@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109673811_904a889ab627f241.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-14.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn57@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674997_16e1fda3d77e1fbb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-15.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn53@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109670906_319bbad0570e6959.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-16.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn25@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109675854_0e45fd0130efe7c4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-19.jpg/aid11702259-v4-728px-Knit-Baby-Pants-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn77@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109677082_0df451513d87723b.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Close a Bag of Chips by Folding It","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>If you don’t have a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Close-a-Chip-Bag\" title=\"Close a Chip Bag\">bag clip</a>, you have a few options when it comes to keeping your chips fresh. The easiest way to do this is to fold the top of the bag over itself multiple times after forcing the excess air out. If you do this, store your chips with the folds facing down and place a heavy object over the folds to keep the bag sealed. Another option is to fold the corners towards the middle of the bag before folding a few layers on top of the corners. Then, stick your thumbs in the corner folds and turn them over the top of the bag to create an airtight seal.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Creating a Simple Fold\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Creating-a-Simple-Fold\">Creating a Simple Fold</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Lay the bag down and smooth the bag out to remove air. Shake the bag a little to let the chips settle at the bottom of your bag. Set your bag of chips on its back so that the label is facing up. Smooth down the top portion of the bag 3-4 times until its flat. Work from the bottom of the bag to the top to remove the excess air from the bag.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Close a Bag of Chips by Folding It Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This method is easy, but it won’t keep the air out unless you store the opening under a heavy item.</li>\n<li>The more air there is the bag, the faster your chips will become stale.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Fold the opening of the bag on top of itself. Rotate the bag so that the opening of the bag is facing you. Grip the corners of the open end with your index finger on top of the bag and your thumbs underneath. Fold the top  of the bag over on top of itself to close the bag.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Continue folding the bag in  layers. With your first fold completed, press down along the seam where you folded it. Then, slide your thumb underneath the fold and grab the top of the bag. Create an additional fold that is the same size as your first fold. Repeat the process until you’ve created 5-6 folds.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Press down along the top of the bag after each fold to keep it closed.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Store the bag upside down on top of itself. Take your bag and flip it upside down so that the folds are on the bottom of the bag. Your bag of chips should stay folded automatically. To keep the folds from unraveling over time, place a vase, bowl, or something heavy on top of the folds to keep them weighed down.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Close a Bag of Chips by Folding It Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Your folds may slowly come undone if you don’t weigh them down at all.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Stronger Fold\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Stronger-Fold\">Making a Stronger Fold</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Lay the bag on a table and flatten the top to remove excess air. Shake your bag a little to collect the chips at the bottom of the bag. Place your bag on a flat surface and lay it on its back so that the label is facing up. Then, use the palm of your hand to flatten the upper half of the bag. Do this 4-5 times to crease the sides of the bag.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Close a Bag of Chips by Folding It Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This method creates the best seal but it requires a little more work. You’ll also need more of the bag to be empty, so you may not be able to do this if your bag is mostly full.</li>\n<li>This method is really hard to pull off if you have a smaller bag of chips. You’re better off simply folding smaller bags over.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Fold the top corners of the bag towards the middle so they meet. Keeping the bag flat, fold each corner of the opened end towards the middle of the bag. Angle each corner downwards so that both corners meet  below the bag’s opening.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Fold the top  over the corners. Keep your corners pressed flat as you pinch the top of the bag at the joints where the corners start to angle down towards the middle of the bag. Carefully fold the top  of the bag down over the top of the corners.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Keeping the bag held down shouldn’t be difficult. The easiest way to do it is to use your middle, ring, and pinky fingers to press them into the table while you’re folding.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Continue folding the top of the bag until you have 2-3 layers. Take your fold and repeat the process. Grab the top of your first fold and create a second fold that’s the same size as your first layer. Repeat this process until you’ve created 2-3 layers. You must have at least  of the corners available below your folds for this to work.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Press your palm flat into the folded sections of the bag to flatten them.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Stick your thumbs into the corner flaps and invert the top of the bag. To seal the bag, hold the folds at the top of the bag down with your index, middle, ring, and pinky fingers. Insert your thumbs between the corners and the bag. Lift the bag up and push your folds down while pulling the corners up to invert the top of the bag and close it on itself.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Essentially, the tension between the corners and the folds at the top will keep the bag sealed.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Once a bag of chips has been opened, they will start to go bad. Consume your chips with the next 1-2 weeks to enjoy them while they’re fresh.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span 24 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"dddf9522c485cebe575a1af0181a8d27","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn87@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109662349_5d5a8b4683540199.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn87@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109662349_5d5a8b4683540199.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn21@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109674792_720faaa12d56a830.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/09/Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid434061-v4-728px-Close-a-Bag-of-Chips-by-Folding-It-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn21@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109672002_e0b57edec78665fc.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Fix a Separated Zipper","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>It's frustrating when zippers break suddenly, such as when their teeth separate and the zipper slider won't open and close them anymore. This can be embarrassing if it's on your pants zipper or if it's on a backpack and all of your things fall out. However, there are several ways of fixing a separated zipper. You can either try to fix the slider itself or realign the zipper by taking it apart and putting it back together. One of these methods is likely to fix the majority of zippers that have separated.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Reducing the Opening On the Zipper Slider\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reducing-the-Opening-On-the-Zipper-Slider\">Reducing the Opening On the Zipper Slider</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Inspect the slider on the zipper. Many times when the sides of a zipper separate and won't go back together as you pull the slider, it's because <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Repair-a-Zipper-Slider\" title=\"Repair a Zipper Slider\">the slider</a> itself is damaged. When you use a zipper often, the slider opening will begin to stretch open a bit. Inspect both ends of the zipper to determine if they have the same opening size. If one end looks wider than the other, then this may be why your zipper failed.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>As the opening increases in size, it puts less pressure on the tracts of the zipper, allowing them to stay separated.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Inspect the rest of the zipper and fix any problems that are apparent. For instance, straighten out any bent zipper teeth that you see. If there are tears in the fabric of the zipper, mend them.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>In some cases, bent teeth on a zipper will cause a zipper to separate. If the zipper teeth are metal, you can use a pair of pliers to straighten them out. If the teeth are plastic, gently try to straighten them with your fingers, as pliers could easily break them off.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Squeeze the opening on the slider to reduce its size. Squeeze the slider on the top and bottom with your fingers or a pair of pliers. This will make the opening inside the slider the correct size once again.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>On one end of the slider there is a middle piece that won't let you squeeze it. On the other end there is no middle piece. That is the side that gets opened and needs to be squeezed back together.</li>\n<li>Don't squeeze the slider too strongly though, as you don't want to make the gap smaller than it should be. You will know the gap is too small if it becomes difficult to pull up and down the zipper slider along the tracks.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Check the zipper. Once you've reshaped the slider, move it up and down the zipper. If it is properly fixed, the slider should go back to opening and closing the zipper right away.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If the zipper still doesn't work, either squeeze the slider more or try another solution.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Removing and Reinserting the Slider\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-and-Reinserting-the-Slider\">Removing and Reinserting the Slider</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Assess whether the slider needs to be realigned. If you have tried to move the zipper up and down, force the zipper sides together, and reduce the opening on the slider, the next thing to try is starting from scratch. If you can see the stops at the top of the zipper and they are metal, taking off the slider and realigning the zipper is possible.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The stops at the top of the zipper are small pieces of metal that are shaped a bit differently from the teeth on the zipper. They are not big pieces and they look similar to teeth but they are slightly larger and are positioned at the very end of each side of teeth.</li>\n<li>If the stops are plastic, you won't be able to take them off and put them back off without breaking them, so you can't use this method.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Remove the top stops. Get a pair of small-tipped pliers and gently open up the stop. The stop it shaped like a \"u,\" so you simply need to open up the side of the stop that is hooked onto the tape of the zipper. Once it is just slightly opened, you can wiggle it and unhook it from the tape.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>It's important to be gentle with the stop and don't cut it or bend it until it breaks. You need to keep it intact.</li>\n<li>Keep the top stops and put them somewhere safe, as you'll need to use them again.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Pull the slider up and off the zipper. Once the tops stops are removed, you will be able to easily pull the slider off the end of the zipper. Taking it off will allow you fix the tracks and then get the slider back in line.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Push the teeth of the zipper together. Start at the bottom of the zipper, the opposite end from where you took off the slider. Push the teeth of the zipper together, making sure that the teeth from the left and right sides alternate.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Put the zipper on top of a hard surface. As you work your way up the zipper, press down on the teeth to pop them into place.</li>\n<li>It is important that the teeth are perfectly lined up. Make sure that once you get to the top of the zipper that you don't have extra teeth on one side. This would mean that the teeth are not lined up.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Reinsert the slider onto the top of the zipper. Once you have realigned the teeth, stick the bottom of the slider back onto the top of the tracks. Insert one track into the bottom of the slider, which is the end without a piece of metal separating the two sides. Then insert the other track.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You will know each side is inserted when several teeth have gone up into the slider and the track won't go any further.</li>\n<li>It's easiest to insert one side and then the other. Putting them both in at once doesn't typically work.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Run the slider up and down to check your work. Pull the slider down a few inches to make sure that it is on track. Move it up and down a bit to make sure it opens and closes the zipper correctly.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Be sure not to pull the slider all the way back up to the top, as it will slide off of the tracks again without the top stops in place.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Reapply the top stops. Once the zipper is working once again, put the top stops back in place. Position them in the spots where they were originally installed. Squeeze the ends of the stops with your pliers until they grip the zipper tape once again.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Fix a Separated Zipper Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Wiggle each stop after you reinstall it to ensure that it is securely in place.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Just because you have a broken zipper, that doesn't mean that your piece of clothing or bag is broken forever. If you can't get the sides back together, you can always <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Replace-a-Zipper\" title=\"Replace a Zipper\">replace the zipper</a> altogether.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Fix-a-Separated-Zipper&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\"
