id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/-QnVZ3NK7OA?t=500\">https://youtu.be/-QnVZ3NK7OA?t=500</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 23 Jul 2020 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"358c6686eb14123168684c157fd14fa3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn83@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662380_9d3222b82f90f4fd.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn83@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109662380_9d3222b82f90f4fd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn89@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109676268_a34292189e1d2e35.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn89@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109675613_5cba9f8cb2b44118.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn57@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676916_f5fe5587147bfa1e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn69@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109671604_39ff3d7d37ed6317.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b6/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn34@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109673555_da8afa633b8cc411.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn97@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109674647_6195474d17847ffe.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b8/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn17@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109674772_cb24eb2671661e75.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn62@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109670924_3434b72f89b70176.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn17@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109675776_d41d558a18cb864d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7088316-v4-728px-Fix-a-Separated-Zipper-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn49@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675090_b970f37d2ec66eaa.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Cover Logos on Clothes","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>There are plenty of valid reasons for removing a logo. If you like expressing yourself through your clothing, there are plenty of patches that are way cooler than corporate logos. Even if you don’t necessarily care about the look of the logo, a company or designer logo is just free advertising, and many people prefer to not walk around covered in corporate symbols. If you have a cool work shirt, removing the logo allows you to convert it into a regular piece of clothing that you can wear anywhere. The only real way to cover a logo completely is to use a patch or applique, which is a thin piece of fabric used for knitting and crafting. Otherwise, you can choose to remove the logo from the clothing.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Hiding the Logo with a Patch\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hiding-the-Logo-with-a-Patch\">Hiding the Logo with a Patch</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Buy a patch to cover the logo up and hide it. You can use any patch to cover a logo so long as it’s big enough to cover it. You can use a patch you already own, or buy a unique patch online. Get an iron-on patch if you want to make it easy to attach to your clothing. If you know how to sew, you can cover your logo with any type of patch.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Logos on Clothes Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Lay your patch on top of the logo and line it up. Lay your clothing down flat. Place your patch or applique directly on top of the logo. Adjust the orientation of the patch to line it up symmetrically with the top and bottom of your clothing. Use the seams on the fabric to visually determine whether the patch is lined up or not.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Logos on Clothes Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-2.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can certainly attach your patch at an angle if you prefer. In this case, you do not need to line the logo up with anything.</li>\n<li>If your patch is heat-activated, do this on an ironing board.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Iron your patch over the logo if it’s heat-activated. If you’re using an iron-on patch, put a piece of cardboard under the fabric and put a clean pillowcase on top of the patch. Turn your iron on medium heat and wait 15-30 seconds for the iron to heat up. Then, run the iron over the patch while pressing down. Move the iron back and forth over the patch to heat the fabric evenly. Do this for 45-60 seconds to activate the adhesive on your patch and attach it to the clothing.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Let the patch air dry for 3-5 minutes so that the glue has time to cure to the fabric.</li></ul></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Sew\" title=\"Sew\">Sew</a> the patch over the logo by hand if you want to stitch it yourself. Put 2-3 sewing pins into the patch and the clothing to hold it in place. Run some stitching thread through the sewing needle and tie a knot to hold it in place. Thread the needle through the back of the patch and pull it through the other side. Then, repeat this process by pushing the needle through the front and pulling it out the back. Continue threading the needle around the patch until you’ve completely attached it to your clothing.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Tie a knot at the end of the stitching thread to hold it in place or leave the needle loose.</li>\n<li>Run the thread just inside the edge of the patch to avoid running thread through the stitching on the edges of the patch. This is less important for appliques, which are usually cut out.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use a <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Sewing-Machine\" title=\"Use a Sewing Machine\">sewing machine</a> if you have one in your home. Stick 2-3 sewing pins into the patch and through the clothing to hold it in place. Run stitching thread through a sewing machine and pull it through to the needle. Lay your patch under the needle and pump the pedal on the machine to begin applying your patch. Continue rotating the patch under the needle until you’ve stitched the entire patch into the clothing.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Logos on Clothes Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-5.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Cut the excess thread off when you’re done.</li>\n<li>You can use any stitch to attach the patch or applique to the clothing. A running stich is the easiest pattern to use for this.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Removing Embroidered Logos\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-Embroidered-Logos\">Removing Embroidered Logos</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Get a seam ripper to cut through the embroidery. A seam ripper is a special sewing tool used to remove threads or stitches. It resembles a pen with 2 prongs at the end and a sharp blade in the middle. The smaller prong is used to remove seams, while the longer prong is used to cut through individual threads or cloth. You can buy a seam ripper online or from a craft or knitting store.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Cover Logos on Clothes Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-6.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If there is a sewing kit in your home, there should be a seam ripper in there.</li>\n<li>You can buy a seam ripper for $3-5.</li>\n<li>Before you do this, turn your clothing inside out to see if there are stitches on the back. If there aren’t, you cannot use a seam ripper to remove the logo. You may be able to melt the glue holding the logo in place with acetone as described in the final section, though.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Poke the fabric next to the logo to see if it damages the clothing. Removing an embroidered logo will damage the clothing if the fabric isn’t porous. To test the fabric, take the long prong on the seam ripper, gently poke the fabric next to the logo, and pull the ripper out. If the fabric isn’t damaged, you can remove the logo without damaging the clothing. If there’s a small hole, removing the embroidery will damage the clothing.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Cut the individual stiches using the long prong of the seam ripper. Brace the fabric with your nondominant hand by pressing down next to the logo. Take the long prong of the seam ripper and dig it under the embroidery without puncturing the fabric underneath. Push the seam ripper forward while pulling the tool away from the clothing. Continue pulling the ripper up until the stitches slide to the back of the seam ripper and tear on the blade. Repeat this process for every section of the logo.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>This will be kind of time consuming if the logo is large or elaborate. You have to cut through all of the stitches to remove them.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Flip the clothing inside out and pull the threads out. Turn your clothing inside out. Use your fingers to pull the threads on the logo from the back. Since you tore the threads on the front, the threads will come right out as you pluck them out. If the threads are really tight against the fabric and you can’t grip them with your fingers, use the small prong on the seam ripper to dig under the threads.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You can also use tweezers to pull the embroidery out.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Rid of Printed Logos\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Rid-of-Printed-Logos\">Getting Rid of Printed Logos</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Iron rubber or plastic logos and peel them off by hand. Soak a pillowcase in water and put it on top of the logo. Then, turn your iron on to a medium heat setting. Wait 15-30 seconds for the iron to heat up and press it on top of the pillowcase that’s covering your logo. Move the iron back and forth over the logo for 45-60 seconds. Then, set the iron down and pull up the pillowcase. Rub the logo firmly with the pad of your finger. The logo will rub off as you continue to apply friction.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>You may need to peel the logo off if it’s sticking to the fabric.</li>\n<li>If the logo won’t come off, apply more heat with your iron and try again. Some stronger logos will require several attempts.</li>\n<li>It can be hard to tell the difference between rubber, vinyl, and plastic. In general, rubber and plastic logos will always reflect light, while some vinyl logos will not. Try ironing the logo and peeling it off before moving on to another solution.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use 100% acetone to dissolve vinyl logos. Get a bottle of pure, 100% acetone. Put on nitrile or rubber gloves and set your clothing down in a tub or sink. Pour the acetone on top of the logo until the logo is completely soaked. Wait 1-2 minutes for the acetone to soak into the fabric. Then, use your finger to rub and peel the logo off. Wash your clothing after doing this to remove the acetone.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br />\n<ul><li>Regular nail polish remover that is less than 100% acetone may work, but pure acetone is much more efficient.</li>\n<li>You can tell if a logo is vinyl by feeling it. If it’s smooth and feels like it’s resting on top of the clothing, it’s probably vinyl.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Remove a logo with a pair of tweezers if it’s old and peeling off. If you want to remove a logo because it’s worn down and old, you can usually use tweezers regardless of what it’s made out of. Grip an edge of the logo with the jaws of your tweezers and pull it up. The logo will probably come off in sections, so continue peeling it off until you’ve removed all of the logo.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>You can use a pin-back button to cover a logo, but it may not sit flush with clothing depending on the material and the size of the logo. Still, this is a fairly good solution if you need to cover a logo quickly.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Hiding the Logo with a Patch\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Hiding-the-Logo-with-a-Patch_2\">Hiding the Logo with a Patch</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Patch or applique</li>\n<li>Iron</li>\n<li>Ironing board</li>\n<li>Cloth</li>\n<li>Thread</li>\n<li>Sewing needle or sewing machine</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Removing Embroidered Logos\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-Embroidered-Logos_2\">Removing Embroidered Logos</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Seam ripper</li>\n<li>Tweezers (optional)</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Getting Rid of Printed Logos\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-Rid-of-Printed-Logos_2\">Getting Rid of Printed Logos</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Acetone</li>\n<li>Iron</li>\n<li>Pillowcase</li>\n<li>Tweezers</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Cover-Logos-on-Clothes&#38;action=edit&#38;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2><div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\"><ol class=\"references\">\n<li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/NGvJ_0sLwz0?t=70\">https://youtu.be/NGvJ_0sLwz0?t=70</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.whowhatwear.com/how-to-iron-on-patches\">https://www.whowhatwear.com/how-to-iron-on-patches</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/fWlDFDmzNp0?t=110\">https://youtu.be/fWlDFDmzNp0?t=110</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.sewingmachinegallery.com/how-to-use-sewing-machine-step-by-step/\">https://www.sewingmachinegallery.com/how-to-use-sewing-machine-step-by-step/</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/28/fashion/snipping-out-annoying-clothing-labels.html\">https://www.nytimes.com/2011/07/28/fashion/snipping-out-annoying-clothing-labels.html</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=62\">https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=62</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-7\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=114\">https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=114</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-8\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=114\">https://youtu.be/cYSC-uyx1zQ?t=114</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/bqN5pjti9gw?t=101\">https://youtu.be/bqN5pjti9gw?t=101</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/WVeGDitPqKo?t=107\">https://youtu.be/WVeGDitPqKo?t=107</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://youtu.be/6fCmj9GAHzw?t=41\">https://youtu.be/6fCmj9GAHzw?t=41</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Jul 2020 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg","linkMd5":"9e2d9b346cc72eac225a5b944e3afd9d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn43@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109662918_41c68c3093d21919.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn43@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109662918_41c68c3093d21919.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/42/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-2.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109670902_ddad3ab91e25e1ca.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-5.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn69@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109676092_de612f039470bb87.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-6.jpg/aid11732424-v4-728px-Cover-Logos-on-Clothes-Step-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn77@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673275_15b3a2afd76cd918.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Declutter a Home Office","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Declutter-a-Home-Office","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>If you’re one of those people with a home office, whether you work from home or just like having a space to organize and pay your bills, then keeping it tidy is a great way to improve your productivity and mood. Unfortunately, over time, your workspace may have gotten messy and cluttered with papers, reports, or mail. But don’t worry – this is an easy problem to fix. Set aside a day to clean up, then implement a strict filing system to keep your home office neat and organized.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Clearing and Sorting Your Items\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Clearing-and-Sorting-Your-Items\">Clearing and Sorting Your Items</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Put aside items that you actually use every day. While some of the clutter in your desk and office might be from things you don’t even use, there are probably several items you use regularly. Items like pens, staplers, writing pads, or highlighters are used often. Take these items and put them aside in a safe place so you don’t get rid of them accidentally.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you aren’t sure what’s important, spend a week working normally and note down when you use each item. By the end of the week, you should have a list of things that you’ve used, showing you which items to keep.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Remove all the loose items from your desk that you don’t use. Once you’ve put aside the important items, take stock of everything else on your desk. There are probably loose papers, broken pens, bills, and other clutter that you don’t even look at. Clear all of this off and put it in a box.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Make sure to look at all the documents you’re getting rid of an confirm there is no sensitive information on them, like bank account numbers. If there are, shred these papers instead of throwing them out whole.</li>\n<li>If you have mementos like pictures or souvenirs on your desk, put them in a separate box so you don’t throw them out by accident.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Empty all of your desk and file cabinet drawers. You might use your drawers as a dumping ground to put things that you don’t have a place for, so the clutter could be pretty bad in here. Start with a blank slate and dump all the drawers out. This way, you can dedicate drawers to a specific purpose when you put the items back.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Be careful when you empty the drawers in case you put anything fragile in there over the years.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Sort everything you find into categories. Once you've removed everything from your desk and drawers, get to work sorting through it. Divide the items into categories. Common ones might be bills, mail, work reports, general office supplies, or others that are personal to you. With everything sorted out, you can put it back in a much more organized way.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Also make a junk pile for things you don't need or use and plan to get rid of them.</li>\n<li>You might find some items that are important, but would fit better somewhere else. Recipes, for example, should be in the kitchen. Move these items elsewhere if you find them.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Throw out everything you don’t use. While you're sorting through your items, separate out the unimportant things. When you're done sorting, throw out all the junk to open up more room in your office.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Important items include business records, medical or ID documents, and bank information. Unimportant things would be outdated credit card statements or receipts, bills that you’ve already paid, and scrap paper or notes that you haven’t look at in years. You might also find loose items that you left in drawers when you didn’t know what else to do with them.</li>\n<li>If you're not sure whether to throw something out, put it in a box labelled \"Two Week Think on It.\" Then, come back to the box every 2 weeks and make a decision on anything in the box.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Dust off your desk and drawers while they’re clear. Dust and dirt have probably built up around your office, especially if you haven’t cleaned in a while. Take the opportunity to dust everything off while the desk is clear. Wipe the desk and drawers with a damp rag or moist wipes before putting everything back.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Remember to clean your computer too. Wipe down the screen and keyboard so the whole workspace looks fresh.</li>\n<li>Do some other cleaning if you have to. Vacuuming the office, for example, is a good way to make the space look and feel cleaner.</li>\n<li>Leave the window open while you work to filter out any dust you kick up while cleaning.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Organizing Your Paper Items\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Organizing-Your-Paper-Items\">Organizing Your Paper Items</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Get a file cabinet if you don’t have one already. If the original clutter was caused by a lack of storage space, then a file cabinet can solve that issue. Get a cabinet that fits your office space and use it to sort all of your documents and other important items so they don’t build up on your desk.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Label all of the folders and file separators you use in the cabinet to stay organized.</li>\n<li>Remember to stick to your filing system if you use a file cabinet. Don’t throw things into the drawers aimlessly.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Dedicate each drawer to a specific category. Don’t treat your desk and file cabinets like junk drawers. Give each drawer a specific purpose that corresponds to your paper categories, like bills, medical records, office supplies, and the like. Stick with this system to keep your workspace organized.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Use file folders to identify items if you have several different categories in the same drawer. Separate bills, bank statements, and business reports with different folders.</li>\n<li>If you tend to have a lot of random items or have a hard time throwing things away, you could dedicate one drawer to miscellaneous items. This is a compromise that lets you keep some clutter, but isolates it in one spot so it doesn’t spread.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Label all your folders, drawers, and binders. A good labeling system will help you stick with the organization plan. Give every drawer, folder, pad, or notebook a specific purpose and label it. Then stick with that system whenever you put something away so everything is in its proper place.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Your labeling system could be simple, like writing “Bills” on a folder. If you prefer a more creative approach, try color-coding the folders with stick labels.</li>\n<li>If your drawers don’t have sections for labels, just use a strip of masking tape and write on it with a marker. Then pull the tape off if the drawer purpose changes.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Use a desktop organizer for important papers and files. Desktop organizers are small bins with compartments that fit easily on desks. You can use one of these to sort the papers and folders you use regularly so they’re right in front of you when you need them. Buy these from office supply stores or online.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Label or color-code each section for better organization.</li>\n<li>If you don’t have many things to sort, then a desktop organizer might be all you need instead of a whole file cabinet.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Create a mail station to sort your bills and other mail. Mail can build up on your desk, and a few tools can help reduce the clutter. Try using a mail basket that attaches to your wall. This organizes your mail and keeps it off your desk.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Use an “In” and “Out” basket to sort the mail that you’ve already handled and the mail that you still have to look at.</li>\n<li>You could also use a bin or basket on your desk for mail sorting, if your desk is big enough.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Reducing Your Paper Use\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Reducing-Your-Paper-Use\">Reducing Your Paper Use</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Print only what’s necessary to reduce clutter. Paper is one of the main reasons for office clutter. Think twice before printing and ask yourself if you really need a physical copy of these files. If not, then look at the document on the computer instead and prevent paper from building up on your desk.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>As an added bonus, you’ll save money on paper and printer ink. It’s also better for the environment to preserve paper.</li>\n<li>If you work from home, most of your work is probably done digitally anyway, so resisting the urge to print is easier than if you worked in an office.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Get rid of papers and books that you can access online. With so many digitized items now, many physical publications are only taking up space. If you regularly look at articles, manuals, or reports, see if you can access them online. If so, then your physical copies aren’t necessary. Recycle or donate them to free up space.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Switch your magazine or journal subscriptions and bills to digital-only. This prevents them from building up in your office.</li>\n<li>See if you can sell or donate books before getting rid of them. Libraries and charities are always look for donations.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Scan important papers and recycle the physical copies. Many of your bills and records can be digitized. Get a scanner or take high-quality photos of them, then shred and recycle the originals. This reduces paper buildup in your office.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-14.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Remember to use a good filing system on your computer so you don’t lose track of the documents. Label everything and put the files in a folder.</li>\n<li>Save sensitive documents on your desktop rather than using cloud storage. These can be hacked and your information could be stolen.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tidying Up Your Desk and Computer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tidying-Up-Your-Desk-and-Computer\">Tidying Up Your Desk and Computer</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Use baskets or bins to organize your office supplies. Pens, markers, staplers, and tape can all clutter up the top of your desk. Get yourself a can or bin for all those items to keep them under control. Remember to put your writing tools back in there every time you're done using them so they don't build up again.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-15.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you have several types of pens or markers and want to keep them separate, use a bin with sections for different items.</li>\n<li>You can dedicate a drawer to larger office supplies like your stapler. This frees up your desktop for more important work items.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Tuck computer and phone cables away. Cables and cords can be a huge reason for desktop clutter. Run them to your desk from a direction that keeps them out of the way. Charging cords, for example, can run behind your desk to stay hidden.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-16.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You can keep cords out of the way with Velcro clips that go along your desk. Buy these at office supply stores.</li>\n<li>If possible, switch to wireless appliances like a USB keyboard and mouse. This cuts down on the amount of wires on your desk.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Combine your computer desktop icons. Don’t forget about your computer desktop. Having tons of icons everywhere can make your work station feel chaotic. Declutter the computer by making desktop folders and placing files in the correct places. Your work station will look much neater afterward.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-17.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 17.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-17.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-17.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Install <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Build-Simple-Floating-Shelves\" title=\"Build Simple Floating Shelves\">floating shelves</a> above your desk for more storage space. A little extra storage space might get rid of your clutter problem. Get a floating shelf kit from a hardware store or build your own. Hang one or more above your desk for new layers of space.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-18.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 18.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-18.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-18.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Remember to keep the new shelves organized. Use them for tidy storage, not as a place to throw things.</li>\n<li>Hanging shelves can also be decorative. A vase or picture frames give a nice atmosphere to your office, and free up your desk for more important items.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Continue cleaning regularly so junk doesn’t build up again. Once you’ve done all that work to declutter your office, don’t let it get messy again. Do a little bit of cleaning and rearranging regularly so your workspace stays neat.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-19.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Declutter a Home Office Step 19.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-19.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-19.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If you need a reminder to clean, try setting a day every month to be your cleaning day.</li>\n<li>Avoid the urge to leave things on your desk or throw them in your drawer at the end of the day. Put everything back in its proper place, or throw it out if it isn’t important.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>During the COVID-19 pandemic, a lot of places might not take donations. If you are donating anything, it might be best to keep it on hold until the pandemic ends.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Declutter-a-Home-Office&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2>\n<ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office\">https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office\">https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-14\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/273026\">https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/273026</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-18\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.inc.com/wanda-thibodeaux/how-to-declutter-your-office-and-create-the-ultimate-creativity-space.html\">https://www.inc.com/wanda-thibodeaux/how-to-declutter-your-office-and-create-the-ultimate-creativity-space.html</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office\">https://www.hgtv.com/lifestyle/clean-and-organize/10-steps-to-an-organized-home-office</a></span>\n</li>\n<li id=\"_note-20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/273026\">https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/273026</a></span>\n</li>\n</ol></div>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"7a34c179bc9310500aaf9e3779bd7b69","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn19@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662616_40ce334c98668a24.webp","author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn19@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109662616_40ce334c98668a24.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/10/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn1@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109676533_4c572656fae17e01.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/82/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn89@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109674636_4d4b360acc300d79.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn49@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109670886_808d976ddd7a7d03.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn97@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109673350_bf9d240b2d8ee96f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn29@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672459_32ac1e9a23061de1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn45@2020_3/2020-07-30/1596109672646_942753970c45d825.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn85@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109677072_011389732b54b7fd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109676563_89af0e6f0f3920f4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/94/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn29@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109676578_b4a36b92b694b6be.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn86@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109671127_bc55429fb07e8b3a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn1@2020_2/2020-07-30/1596109672350_60cb36b913208246.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109672826_85c642ecdf4f8f5c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-14.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn9@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109676276_ca08423304fecedb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-15.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn54@2020_5/2020-07-30/1596109673541_1eafa7f0070f3b82.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-16.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn78@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109672327_10ded5c6e1d62749.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-17.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn65@2020_6/2020-07-30/1596109675148_13ac51b7ae0b928f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-18.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn57@2020_4/2020-07-30/1596109676106_f6a9a461baaa40ac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-19.jpg/aid2203450-v4-728px-Declutter-a-Home-Office-Step-19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn10@2020_1/2020-07-30/1596109671955_aefc4eec7ba8c5cf.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-07-30 19:47:41","updatedTime":"2020-07-30 11:47:41","title":"How to Dry Clothes While Camping","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Whether you got caught in the rain, went fishing, or had to walk through a stream, wet clothes are just a fact of life while camping. Fortunately, there are lots of ways to dry out your wet clothes. The easiest way is an old-fashioned clothesline tied between 2 trees. If you don’t have a rope, then there are a few other methods that can dry your clothes just as fast.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Setting up a Clothesline\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Setting-up-a-Clothesline\">Setting up a Clothesline</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Tie a rope between 2 trees in a sunny spot. An old-fashioned clothesline is the best method for drying clothes on a camping trip. Find 2 trees in a sunny spot and close enough together for you to tie a rope between them. Wrap the rope around both trees and tie a knot to connect the rope ends.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 1.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-1.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-1.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You don’t necessarily need trees. Any kind of pole or stake will work as well.</li>\n<li>If you don't have rope, any other material that you can tie around a tree will work as well. Paracord, twine, or string can do the trick as well. Always include some materials like these in your camping pack.</li>\n<li>Try to find a spot with good airflow as well. A light breeze will dry your clothes much faster.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Squeeze out all of your clothes to remove excess water. Your clothes will dry faster if you wring them out a bit before hanging them, especially if they’re soaked. Squeeze and twist each wet item to get rid of excess moisture.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-2.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Try rubbing the clothes between your hands too. The friction can start evaporating some of the water.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Drape your wet clothes over the rope with some space between items. After wringing the clothes out, hang each item over the rope. Spread and flatten each one out so it dries faster. Also leave a few inches of space in between each item so there’s good airflow.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-3.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>You could also pack some clothespins to help keep the clothes in place. This is helpful if it’s windy.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li></ul></li>\n<li>Wait about 1 hour for the clothes to dry. Depending on how sunny and windy it is, the clothes could take between 20 minutes and 2 hours to dry. Check back in about an hour to see if they’re dry enough. If not, leave them on the line to dry some more.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-4.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Keep an eye on the weather while your clothes are drying. If it gets cloudy, be prepared to bring your clothes into your tent quickly if it starts raining.</li></ul></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Build-a-Campfire\" title=\"Build a Campfire\">Build a campfire</a> a few feet away to speed up the process. The increased heat from a campfire will make the water evaporate faster. Build a campfire about  from the clothesline and let it burn while the clothes dry.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-5.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Always follow campfire safety guidelines. Clear the area of any dry vegetation, dig a pit, and surround it with rocks to keep the fire contained. Always extinguish the fire with water or dirt before leaving it unattended.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n<li>Never put the fire directly under the clothes. This will burn them.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Drying without a Clothesline\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Drying-without-a-Clothesline\">Drying without a Clothesline</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Wrap the wet clothes in a dry towel to soak up moisture. This method won’t get your clothes completely dry, but it’ll soak up a lot of water. Wring your clothes out a little and lay them on top of a dry towel. Fold the towel over the clothes and press it down. Leave the clothes there for 20-30 minutes while the towel absorbs the moisture.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-6.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Make sure the towel was completely dry before you start this method.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Lay your clothes on a warm rock in the sun. If you don’t have a rope or clothesline, then a warm rock can dry your clothes quickly. Lay any wet items flat onto the rock and make sure they aren’t touching each other. Let them sit in the sun for about an hour.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-7.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>The rock might be dirty, so try wiping it off a little before placing any clothes down.</li>\n<li>If you have several wet items, then you’ll probably have to find more than one rock or dry your clothes in groups.</li>\n<li>If it's windy out, weigh down the clothes with smaller rocks or similar heavy items. Otherwise, they might blow away.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Drape your clothes over the roof of your tent. Your tent is another good backup spot to hang wet clothes. Lay all the clothes out flat and leave some space between all the items. Check back in about an hour to see if the clothes need more time to dry.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-8.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Make sure the top of your tent isn’t wet, especially if it rained recently. Wipe it down with a towel first.</li>\n<li>Since the tent won’t be as warm as the rock, it’ll probably take longer for clothes to dry here.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Hang wet clothes on a string inside your tent if it’s raining. If you have a rope or string but it’s raining outside, you can try drying them inside your tent. Tie the rope across your tent and hang the wet clothes on it like a clothesline. Leave any windows open to increase the airflow in your tent and dry the clothes faster.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-9.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>If the clothes are dripping, don’t hang them over your sleeping bag. You might get wet while you’re sleeping.</li>\n<li>The clothes will dry slower if it’s raining because the air is damp. It’ll probably take a few hours for your clothes to dry with this method.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Tie wet clothes to your pack if you’re traveling. If you’re hiking and can’t stop to set up a clothesline, you can still dry some clothes while you’re on the move. Use clips or string and tie them to your pack. The wind and sun will help dry them out faster.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Dry Clothes While Camping Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-10.jpg/aid11847268-v4-728px-Dry-Clothes-While-Camping-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>This is best for smaller items like socks and underwear, but you can try it on some larger pieces like shirts too.</li>\n<li>Check behind you every so often to make sure you don’t drop any clothes.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Things You&#039;ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>String or rope</li>\n<li>Campfire</li>\n<li>Tent</li>\n<li>Dry towels</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>If your clothes got wet, change into dry ones before you go to sleep. You'll be more comfortable and will avoid hypothermia.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n<li>If you left wet clothes in a plastic bag, don’t leave them in for more than a day or two. Otherwise mildew might start growing.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Dry-Clothes-While-Camping&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span
